posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428037
Jdownloader2 is a download manager. It automatically saves links from direct download hosts when you copy them and organizes them in a queue. You can then choose when you want the downloads to start. It has many other functions, such as downloading all images from 4chan threads, or from Sadpanda, or saving Youtube videos with subtitles. It can also encode links in a "DLC" file, which offers a layer of protection for those files.
Even though JDownloader2 is free and open source software, the installer is often packaged with adware from places like CNet. The JAR version is just a self-extracting java-based zip file, which in theory is adware free.
I make no guarantees. Scan every software you download and make sure you read installation screens carefully, all the usual things you should be doing already.

>>6437858
Making your art look good is important, but the most important aspect of art is that of communication. Communication of concept, of feeling. Like this image here >>6437863 manages to convey the intended feeling so well that you can practically feel it yourself, despite it being technically shitty.
Someone like Krenz who makes technically beautiful work, but it's all just the same boring portraits of women with bob cuts over and over, may be popular in the sense that lots of people will share it and look at it and go "wow that's so pwetty! :3", but the mark it leaves on the viewer is shallow. They'll leave a like, maybe use it as their phone background or something, and never think about it again. But soulmaxxed work will stick with you, and you'll end up going back to it time and time again to soak up that feeling one more time.

Keep in mind that soulmaxxing does not equal shitty artwork, I would list kokimantarou as one of the most soulful artists I know of and his work is incredibly polished and good looking. Every one of his sketches and finished works exude soul.

posts.com:
>>6366575
>spend more than 10 minutes
All my drawing attempts are agonzingly slow as I spend ages deliberating every single line. I can't imagine getting something done in only ten minutes.
>pick an easier subject
I genuinely don't understand what supposedly makes a subject easier or harder to draw. Everything past basic geometric shapes/forms seems impossibly difficult. I've seen people claim that rocks and trees are easy, which seems crazy to me given that they have such incredibly complex shapes and textures.
>copy literal lines and squares that you drew
I can copy drawings without much issue. The difficulty of drawing for me isn't in measuring or line placement, but in figuring out how the subject could be depicted as a drawing in the first place. I don't have an intuitive understanding of what I'm supposed to be marking with lines, or a clear idea of what process people actually use to draw things. I can also never mentally picture what a drawing of any particular subject would look like. As such, there's very little actually guiding my efforts, which is presumably why I always end up with bizarre indecipherable scribbles.

>>6367712
I had similar problem, but I generally solve it in the canvas, and I let fuck ups ignite more ideas, if I can't picture it, time to look at refs and do some iterations. A good exercise is picking an object like a banana, observe it for a minute, notice the contours, textures, distinctive shapes, now get rid of the banana and draw it as you recall, take your time. Now a copy of it now, check the differences between the 2 drawings.

Some cheap workaround for coming up with something is creating a square in an isometric angle, and just put stuff some simple subjects in it, or you can do it with wonky perspective, but keep a basic angle of view, use your room as reference if you want. Like looking at your desk and pretend that's a little village you're looking at. If you're autistic you can make dioramas too. Also try sculpting, even plastiline is good enough, it's just to start to get you thinking spatially, you need to develop that awareness to think above just abstract lines into a white void, if you need an extra push rely on reference for ideas and details.
Even for awareness you need awareness, it's not just about aping things, but being present, if you have different perspectives you've got yourself better odds at solving problems in your art process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The only "masteries" are

>line quality

>Perspective

>Anatomy

>Values


Line quality is the best to learn first, deciding what's thick and what's thin, using lines to imply the shape instead of perfectly tracing it out. Anatomy is next, its just measurements. The head is as complex as the entire body, but the key is consistency. Perspective is being able to rotate what you drew and draw it in another angle, usually a more interesting one. Values are colors and shading.

There are things like composition which I would call a mastery but its something you can learn the entire time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I will translate the OP's chart into words for you autists, with some additional neg levels:

level -2: cant draw lines of any sort , and cannot draw shapes
level -1: can draw lines and simple shapes
level 0: multiple shapes that look human, but fill no 3d space and are not proportional
level 1: proportional and symmetrical
level 2: a minimum understanding of 3d space
level 3: a more complex pose (limited to frontal, 3/4 view, profile)
level 4: Even more complex pose, includes other normal viewing angles - any angle that is not frontal, 3/4, or profile, more subtle control elements.
level 5: Starting to add more extreme perspective control - frogs eye view, birds eye, ants eye, fish eye, perspective and scenery
level 6+: impossible to tell from a single image - history of being "in control of style" with the ability to duplicate/replicate whatever styles the person likes.

Also take the other chart that goes with that one.

>>6421995
yeah, that chart is probs a bit of a rough read for a beg. but a useful concept it outlines is that you can 'level up' different technical drawing skills independently of each other to an extent. whereas in your framework, one might get the impression that any sort of aptitude in one of your levels implies mastery over previous levels.

>>6424819
>>6426198
this anon here (or maybe these are 2 different anons) thinks that their image is at 'level 2 or 3' because it displays a 'minimum understanding of 3d space'. which it actually totally does. but that doesn't mean they've mastered drawing simple shapes, a 'level -1' skill. or that they can draw proportionally or symmetrically, 'level 1'.

the chart outlines that, in reality, you can work on all of these proposed levels at the same time, and depending on your needs and the types of images you wish to draw, focus more on some than others.

pic related is from this artists' twitter who works in a very flat, graphic style:
https://twitter.com/WarwickJC/media
I think a failing of the chart, as well as your own framework, is that they're not able to adequately classify an image like this, clearly pro level work, that isn't leaning on crazy 3d space manipulation or anatomical knowledge.
largely because of the types of images the creator of the graph is interested in drawing: like anime pin ups or whatever. to be fair I think they admit this themselves.
Just useful to let begs know that really strong line and shape confidence, with mastery over proportion, symmetry and other 'low level' skills can lead to a 'pro level' image like the one we see here.
(also, you can see on this guy's twitter that he does have mastery over 3d space, and I'm sure he also has mastery over anatomy and all that figurative good stuff. you can certainly find artists and graphic designers who haven't felt the form, not even once, but have a really strong sense of shape, leading to pro level work. probably not figurative stuff though.)

>>6431321
I don't think you need to focus on any one art fundamental. rather just be conscious of the fact that there's infinite room for growth along any of the art fundamentals, you can always push the horizon.

Right now, it's really not the case that any one of your art fundamentals is significantly stronger than any other, no use putting one on the back burner. you're gonna have to keep focusing on all of them and let a year or so pass before you evaluate strengths and weaknesses again.

You'll need books and courses on perspective, figure drawing, composition. find them in the artbook thread or video course thread, maybe. there should be stuff marked for begs right?
do a very small amount of hoarding, peruse over what you have and start following along with whichever courses seem to produce images similar to ones you'd like to produce right now.
Then it's just a matter of drawing a lot

as for this:
>So basically I should learn how to draw simple shapes (like squares and circles (without perspective) ) and draw things proportionate or symetrical
My advice: put your mind in that of a teenage girl. they're very powerful at drawing hearts and stars and things. because their diaries are full of that stuff, boys names they like wrapped in multiple hearts with arrows and shit flying out of them. and every time they write jason's name they'll try to make the hearts more prettier and have the stars twinkling more pika-pikaly, do you get what I'm saying? consider the sheer tonnage of symmetric shapes they're pumping out and making conscious effort to improve upon. there's no burning out here. there's always another boy on the horizon, and viscerally, they need the hearts to be more symmetric, VISCERALLY. like the need you have to beat off, I'm serious.
so don't break your neck drilling this shit. find chill ways of repeatedly drawing shapes that conform to your own personality. just another instance of finding ways to apply fundies to shit you personally care about.

>we both pick a character or series were interested in
>she would do the pose we plan to draw as reference and I'd take the photo
>I would normally do the line art, and then either I do the colouring or she does the colouring

That’s kind of the heart of the problem, isn’t it? It honestly doesn’t really matter what resource you pick to learn from as long as you consistently work through the material and don’t just jump ship if you don’t get it right at first. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428944
Just do Bargue plates. It's slow and tedious busywork but it'll teach you relative measuring and train your eye so you can catch your mistakes more easily and play spot the difference between your study and the original better.
Don't binge the whole thing, just a bit everyday. It's fucking boring but it works, and once you have a good eye for proportions and accuracy studying is easier.
You actually plateau pretty fast when only drawing as a hobby with little to no studying like most people did as children/teens. Deliberate practice is the only way anyone improves, but if you don't draw for fun and don't mix studying with drawing what you like you'll be miserable and burn out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428944
if you're having eyeballing issues, try practicing with graph paper and overlaying a grid on your reference to match and have it side by side to match. instead of tackling an overwhelming amount of detail at once, you break it down by matching the lines/details on the smaller squares.

pic related. it should help your sanity a bit since you'll see progress as long as you're autistic about the accuracy of the line placements in the squares.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428960
That sounds like a nice, good practice
Thank you! I'll keep it in mind

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428973
no problem. as you advance you can enlarge those squares until eventually it's 4x4 or none at all. the key is to be super autistic about line placement to train your accuracy. good luck.

Depends on where you’re at, skill-wise and what your goals are. But in order from when I started to now, some books I’ve found helpful are:
Vilppu drawing manual, along with the video lectures
Simultaneously, The first 10-20 pages of any book on perspective to give you a rough idea of 1,2 ,3 point perspective to aid you in the goal of drawing boxes using intuition.
Hampton
Anatomy for sculptors
That Tom fox anatomy book is pretty cool.
And lots of copying art from your favourite artists. And lots of figure drawing.

posts.com:
>>6408712
>a single year
>365 days in a year
if we multiply that by any amount of time, we can get a certain number of hours in a year
so
>1 hour == 365 hours total
>2 hours == 730 hours total
>3 hours == 1095 hours total
>4 hours == 1460 hours total
>5 hours == 1825 hours total
>6 hours == 2190 hours total
typically, if we break down skills into their micro-facets, we can learn something in about 25 hours
if we're really bad at that subject, it might take 50 hours but you'll usually achieve ability before that time

for instance, if you wanted to draw hands, it's not going to take you 10,000 hours as some autists suggest but rather 25 to 50 hours total
this is 25 to 50 hours of actual drawing not getting up to get a drink of water and then shit posting on /ic/ and then including that time into your timeframe of drawing

even though, as mentioned before, it wouldn't take 50 hours but lets say it does, here's the progression if we were to learn micro-skills (drawing hands or other very specific things)
>365 hours == 7 micro skills
>730 hours == 14 micro skills
>1095 hours == 21 micro skills
>1460 hours == 29 micro skills
>1825 hours == 36 micro skills
>2190 hours == 43 micro skills
This means that if you do the bare minimum of drawing every single day for at least an hour, you SHOULD have become at least comfortable drawing at least 7 micro skills
hell, even if you split the 7 micro-skills learned in those 365 hours and say that the person did the absolute BARE minimum to learn just ONE micro-skill
>7/2 (30m) == 3.5 micro-skills
>3.5/2 (15m) == 1.75 micro-skills
this means that if you draw for a bare minimum of 15 minutes per day, focusing on a specific micro-skill, you HAVE to at least be good or at least decent at that one ability

there's no way you spend 50 hours drawing Loomis heads (unless you don't understand form, which in that case you need to study perspective and form before learning to draw the human body) and still draw it like shit

>>6428967
Tried out SG Pen and the Ink Brush, wasn't close to it. So I made this custom brush from a hodge podge of a bunch of brush materials I cannibalized.

I'm not particularly skilled at art, and especially at anime so sorry for the bad drawing. This was to see if I could get close to the original. It was drawn in 1600x2000 then cropped down mainly with the brush size between 12, 16, 20, 24, and 32 depending on what the line thickness is. It's not a good brush for a single line drawing. Instead, you'll have to draw over your lines multiple times to get it to be thick. Keep it light and fast for the "skippy" thin lines. I highly suggest holding your pen either the way Nagabe holds his pen for solid lines and a looser grip for the skippy ones.

https://files.catbox.moe/1ndnwq.sut

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428274
Just got this, extremely disappointing compared to the color & light book.
I feel like color & light offered a well rounded balance of theory, technical information and examples that other books lack and is exhaustive.

The composition and narrative book is a by-the-numbers text dump of golden ratio, rule of thirds, dark foreground, light background type stuff and offers no examples from Greg Rutkowski himself via thumbnails/sketches or other studies to show practical examples.

Framed Ink 1 & 2, Creative Illustration by Loomis and Edgar Paynes composition of outdoor painting all offer much more.

3DTotal back to their usual low quality books.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6435278
You can learn anatomy in med school, but you still won't be able to draw it well. Figure drawing is learning to draw the figure. Learning anatomy is purelly informational knowledge. It does help you understand what you are trying to represent, or when drawing from imagination to know where to position things, but it isn't drawing information. Most pepole say you should start with figure drawing, when you feel confortable with it but you feel you are being held back by not knowing the specifics of the muscles and body parts, then you go to anatomy.

I really see Trad and fine art the only way desu.
That being said if you are tying to go commercial it really depends on the client. There are a few things to bank on,
-A client may only want a certain artist for whatever reason.
-illustration for books and music might be at biggest risk for AI since they are most easily susceptible to the cheapness and convenience of AI.
-doing what AI can't/AI limitations. This is honestly a cope but in the interim if you can identify AI limitations and exploit them then you have your seat at the table. But this is only going to be usefull for the top 1% of artists and only for a microsec as the tech has and continues to advance at record ultralight speeds. Even still this will quickly end and then only a 0001% of artists will continue to be competitive to AI.
-using AI, the end all, but this gets murky. Is it AI art or AI assisted art if you i.e use it to modify or outpaint your work?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6438118
Fair warning, whenever something like this comes up the shills will resort to the "well it's just overfitting, if it weren't overfitting then it would be okay" argument.
"Overfitting" is what happens when you get output that's selected from a point that's *too close* to the original datapoint(s) within the latent space, thus creating output recognizable as the original image data. This most generally happens when there's not enough data points to interpolate between, meaning that it has to pull from one wholesale. But you'll even see this happening *completely by accident*, as you can see with the example in picrelated.
The thing you should all keep in mind is that overfitting is not the problem, it is a SYMPTOM of the system's inherent flaw- it relies entirely upon the interpolation of images, and thus cannot meaningfully change any of its input, only obfuscate it by blending it with enough similar inputs.

I work at a fabric factory during the industrial revolution in Virginia and my boss recently became obsessed with loom technology. One day he asked my colleague to send him a folder of prior works he's done for the company (40-50 high quality bolts of fabric with a very distinct pattern). Two days later, he comes out with a special mechanism for efficient weaving - and even had the guts to put his own name in the model title. The mechanism does an ok job - not great, but enough to fool my textile-savvy bosses that they can now "make fabric like that colleague - hundreds at a time". These are their exact words. They plan to exploit this to the max, and turn existing weavers into finishers. Naturally, my colleague, who has developed his style for 30+ years, feels betrayed. The automated fabric isn't as good as his original work, but the bosses are too fashionably challenged to spot the mistakes.

The most depressing part is, they'll probably make it profitable, and the overall quality will drop.

>>6433071
What program are you using? Generally, the blur tool's not for shading. It's for, you know, blurring. But you shouldn't even need it if you're using an airbrush for more distant shadows. You should probably stick to soft/hard round brushes for now, and maybe experiment with some watercolor if you're feeling snazzy. And of course, study how shapes actually receive/occlude light. You can get really far with smart usage of gradients, a hard brush, and a soft brush for bounce light.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6408922
>$100-200
used 1st/2nd gen ipad pro 12.9"
>$200-400
used 3rd/4th gen ipad pro 12.9
refurbished kamvas 22 plus
new kamvas pro 16
>$400-700
3rd/4th gen ipad pro 12.9
Kamvas 22 plus
Kamvas 24 plus
>$700+
4k Kamvas 24
cintiq 24hd

XP-Pen is another alternative, but their color/contrast isn't as good as huion's, and most of their tablets use an antiglare film instead of etched glass.

If you want to buy once and cry once, wacom is the industry standard, but will cost you your first born for no noticeable benefit over modern chinkshit.

You could also go for something like an older cintiq 24 from 2012 for about the same price as a modern kamvas 24, but you'll have 10 year old tablet tech which was kinda shit in comparison to what we have now.

posts.com:
It dawned on me that most people don't know what art even is, and that includes people on /ic/. And that affects the discussion around AI too.

I'll explain:
Take pic related, a famous painting today. This painting was controversial at its time, and panned, as it's not good art and even plain embarrassing.
Why?
Because it's silly, pathetic and juvenile. Think of what the artist, a young Cabanel, is saying with this pic. "Lucifer was just like me, a young misunderstood genius who was wronged!" and he painted it with all of his skill as big as he could make it, and made Lucifer as buff as a caricature, even compared to classic greek sculptures of Zeus. Lucifer being more buff than Zeus shows him as physically powerful and "healthful", which is a failure to understand the classical worship of beauty as virility and might. Lucifer is crying miserably, it doesn't make sense for him to exude power and health to such extreme extent. It rightfully made the masters of the time cringe.

In degenerate, uneducated post-modernity none of this matters. Only the "product" and the "skill" matters, that's why most people have very little skill at all, and you become a "master" with a third of the skill of a 21 year old artist from centuries ago, when pursuing a purpose is what forces you to gain the skill to represent it. And that's always recognition from other humans, not master in itself.

In conclusion, skill was never what mattered. You can find examples of doodles and memes being far more popular than skillful art that took dozens of hours. Art was always about the artist, the message his art tries to convey, the communication. How the skill is used and for what purpose, rather than how much skill is used. This should frame how AI art is viewed. Art can win in skill, but it can't win in message because it has none. Focus on the meaning of your art and you will never have anything to fear from AI.

tl;dr: skill in art matters very little compared to the meaning of the subject.

Are you going to paint a flat Jesus, or are you going to break the hearts of believers and kings at every sight of your work, winning fame and wealth? This ambition is what rightfully drove those great pieces as the ultimate connection between artist and audience.
And I agree with those that say Picasso was overrated. A lack of skill and familiarity with a subject is all that's needed for some great *progressive* results, like in pic related...

>>6435657
The barrier to entry in art is high if you didn't start young. When you're young, you aren't as hard on yourself and are more likely to be pleased with your results even if they look like shit, and just through repetition and time you'll reach a somewhat adequate level. If you reach a point where you can produce works that are at least halfway to your liking, it's much easier to grind fundamentals through dedicated practice since you have some existing grasp to apply it all to and enjoy the results of your improvement. If you're starting in your twenties or older with the drawing capacity of an 8 year old, grinding basics can feel like a complete waste, since you're basically building from a true zero, unable to produce anything that you're even partway pleased with, and your "fun time" drawings will tend to continue to look like shit for quite a while.

It's like why an active construction worker will have a much easier (and more enjoyable) time when taking up formal weightlifting than will an obese couch potato who has to "grind" basic shit like standing for more than five minutes and doing exercises with 5 pound dumbbells.

please stop doing this—I don't know why undersized heads are so popular with artists who draw this body type because it's not as if your head shrinks when your body gets heavier. Microcephaly is not a marker of "fertility." posts.com: when do you save as .jpg or .png?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413358
.png for images in black and white or very few colors, .jpg for paintings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413358
If file size isn't an issue .png is preferable since PNGs are have lossless compression unlike JPGs. This effectively means if a .jpg is opened and edited multiple times it loses information and degrades in quality.

The reason you would choose .jpg over .png for paintings or coloured work is because of printing, which may not be relevant to your needs. The reason for this is .png is in RGB not in CMYK which is what's used in printing so there is a risk of discrepancy with the colour. There are other ways to address this besides using .jpg and it's very situational, so overall I would still say .png the preferable choice.

please explain these in terms so that a retard can understand
>form
>values
>gesture

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6416834
>form
Making a 2d image look 3d by applying perspective.

>value
in the absolute dumbest terms, it indicates a plane change and/or allows the viewer to separate objects from another. See the example. If all the squares were black, it would look like one shape instead of 3 separate shapes. On a single cube, it would indicate the direction the light source.

>gesture
Difficult to understand unless you have some semblance of form. If you combine all of the small shapes of a figure into one large shape, the gesture is essentially the "motion" or curve the large shape is making. Usually this is one big curve called the "line of action" and doesn't necessarily only apply to figure drawing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6420642 >>6420663
Ok... This is really complicated. I have made hours and coutless of tests about this. The main problem is that the image color profile goes through layers and layers of softwares.

It's all messed up. For instance:
1) The new photo viewer of Windows manages colors in a different way from the old one, which is still installed in the system.
2) A program like CSP does not use color management (you can use the color proof, but the color picker will be wrong).
3) On Windows you can add the color profiles as "advanced color profile", but no one knows what it does because there is not a documentation about it (avoid this setting).

The more I test stuff, the more I get headache. I have just setted everything as sRGB IEC61966-2.1, and when I save the image, I save it without embedding the color profile and coverting it to sRGB (the coversion should be useless because I worked already in sRGB color space). I'm sorry that I can't really answer.

Also, an unrelated thing. Stuff about color proof in grayscale and gamma.
https://gregbenzphotography.com/luminosity-masking/how-to-optimize-your-gray-working-space-for-better-luminosity-masks/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6423798
vanishing points with enclosed scenes are kind of tricky. if they're far enough you can kind of estimate them without much issue. if you work in digital you can zoom out quite far and add guidelines, but i'm not sure how practical it'd be in traditional.
what i find helpful, is often things will share horizon lines. for example, if you wanted to rotate an object that's otherwise in a one point perspective scene, the point itself would be in a different place, but it'd share it's horizon with that first point (i visualise this as it sliding along the horizon line). if it was rotated vertically, i'm not sure if there's a vertical equivalent to a horizon, but you'd essentially do the same thing above/below the "main" vanishing point.
it being rotated both horizontally and vertically starts to get a bit complicated. if you're struggling with perspective, don't worry about this for now
a character or figure would generally share it's vanishing point with the scene, but it depends. as it's more organic and rounded vs a cube or object, i wouldn't worry about it too much as long as the horizon/viewpoint looks okay and is generally consistent with the rest of the scene. the other anon's suggestion about drawing them in a box can be helpful to get a feel for it/keep them in scale.
i think this can be hard to visualise with text alone, lmk if you need any clarification or examples and good luck

In english, crayon means a stick of chalk or wax. Like picrel.
In French, it means "pencil". Think regular pencil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6423798
Just imagine enclosed scenes as if you're inside a "box", logically if the structure has right angles it converges somewhere in the horizon line, if you need visualize it, instead of working on an enclosed canvas, create a frame for your piece, then create this big box in 2pp that expands outside of the frame, you'll have already decided where your eye level or horizon line is, then just place each vanishing point where you want them to be, this is for your box, and any other object that aligns with said box.
Basically, your creating a box where things are going to sit, then you'll play camera man and adjust what you want to show on the plane. You can freehand it first then do a small/medium sketch with accurate perspective then blow it up in whatever size you're actually doing the painting. A common mistake for people doing perspective is they start big and go straight at it without any idea at the blank page, from experience it simply doesn't work and you'll get frustrated and will end up rushing it/stopping.
Perspective drawings are harder because they deal with more elements in the plane, so you'll you have to break it down in steps, plan your painting, get some dirty small sketches out first, if you're doing it trad they can be 5x7 cm, in digital something like 640x480 will do, you can use a big canvas and create a few squares for these sketches, you'll have room for the box process (you may end up not doing this anymore in the future, but it has a few other uses anyway) and you'll be doing different iterations right there, and you can get them out quick. Using reference is also suggested, just don't go blind expecting to create a final result right off the bat if you have no mental image or an idea of how things actually look like.
Also watch Vandruff's 1994 perspective lectures, it deals with different kind of measurement systems that may be useful for you, like projecting measurements on space based on translating divisions from 2D measurements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6424704
Don't ctrl+Z too much. A "correct" line isn't necessarily a good one.
I don't know if that's your case, but drawing lines very timorously like you're performing open heart surgery is generally what makes them feel dead. If you zoom in on a high res versions of drawings you like, you'll probably find a lot more overlaps and small gaps than you would've thought.
That's not to say you should be careless, just that you shouldn't sacrifice what looks good for what you think would be proper.
If you have trouble getting out of the mindset of just tracing the sketch try lowering the opacity more, gaussian blurring it, or changing the colour if you don't do that already.

posts.com: wtf is gesture and figure drawing?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6433923
"gesture drawing" as an activity is a huge meme. It comes from Nicolaides, who couldn't draw for shit.

"Gesture", on the other hand, refers to the pose of the figure. Animators focus on this a lot because the posing and mannerisms of the figure is their whole job. Comic artists and storyboard artists also focus on acting a lot too.

The "gesture" is not a series of wobbly lines. I like Vilppu, but he really created a lot of confusion when he refers to the gesture as a specific thing you do, and not as one aspect of your finished drawing. Proko and Hampton also jumped on this stupid train of thought too. Steve Huston's a bit out there with his "gesture" as "long axis"

tl;dr, just focus on figure drawing, learning construction, anatomy, and loosening up of your poses. Gesture drawing is a /beg/ trap

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6437620
Doing things sight-size makes it easier to check the differences. Making it more practical is better than making it unproductively difficult and frustrating for yourself, even if you think it feels like cheating you're doing a lot of work that a person mindlessly tracing would never even think about.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HMX3K3YMbd8
Dorian Iten has some videos of himself doing copies and accuracy exercises and even he does the same thing, same if you look up people doing Bargue on analog.
When you study from life or a reference you won't always have that luxury anyway so it's not like you won't exercise that muscle. You could try out doing some plates with only comparative measuring if you want a challenge, but the amount you draw is more important than how inconvenient the process is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6430229
attempt 3 and 4 are your best ones.

look up prokos explanation on gesture, yes, dudes a fucking twat, but his explanation mixed with vilppu's if you know it you know it explanation should get you there.

I recommend doing some bargue plates, yes gesture is loose and not meant to be perfectly proportional, but it helps alot to be ballpark where you want to be. I also suggest that you make a point for the head, and a point for the feet, make a line that follows the spine and the branch that off for the legs when you do stuff like the first image, fact of the matter is vilppu already has proportion down so fucking well he needs no guides, but you... well you are a newbie, you need something to tell you if you have proportions correct from the get go, you are probably going to want to learn how to measure with a pencil. you know the stereotype of the artist tongue out to the side, thumb on pencil, learn to do that.

getting proportions correct instantly makes your art FAR better

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434264
measure the proportions between head, pelvis and feet and just get faster at getting those close enough to not matter, if you can even just use a mouse, an image off the the right on the computer, and then draw the dots for head pelvis and feet proportionately larger or smaller, put the image on a different layer and do it again on a new layer over and over, later on after you get 5-10 of these done, enlarger or shrink the image and see if it fits where you put the dots, if it does, awsome, if it doesn't, figure out why it doesn't.

proportion is a make or break thing for any piece and the faster you can figure out its fucked the sooner you can fix it or redo it.

I just looked up asg/s accuray images, fuck that for now

https://archive.org/details/C.BargueDrawingCourse/mode/2up

largely a bargue plate wants you to draw a single line and gain proportions base on that line, doing this will GREATLY help compared to the copying illustration stuff from that thread, especially their borderline retarded explanation.

holy shit, I tried to find youtube demos of this, but all I can find are people using borderline grid methods for copying the image defeating the thing it tries to instill in you, measuring proportions. the fact is that most people don't have the ability to buy or access to busts and live models intimidate people, so the majority of the book is reference material.

you draw a line down, and place 2 points, from there every single line you make uses those two points as reference and the line for scale. doing it this way helps alot with instilling measured proportions as a core thing you don't even need to think about. If you want to do the illustrations rather than the plates I won't stop you, but you should do it the plate method, not their method.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6437528
need is very relative, if I remember right the draftsman's postcase was proko right? keep in mind what they usually do, as in reference a real model or a real life object, so for them to keep themselves in practice, or just to keep sharp for when they use a real model, they would print it off and put it about as far away as they would normally draw form.

I also assume that them printing it off gives them enough distance from it to not be able to just copy side by side, I mean they are still copying it sure, but there is a massive fucking difference between copying with referencing lines for proportion and a grid.

Personally I have a multi monitor setup, 1 4k 55 inch tv and one 22 inch penable display, so I could easily put the image on the 4k and then work on the second monitor, im also getting a tablet soon as a gift to myself which again would put me a step or two away from one of the displays, but even if I worked off one display my 4k has enough resolution i could take 1/3rd the screen for the image and work on the other 2/3rds of the screen.

now if I work exclusively from my 1080p... the reference images are a little on the small side, so printing them off would probably help just for clarity sake, but like I said need is relative. I could work with it side by side, but the problem on 1080p would be the ability to do a borderline grid method, and not really being able to draw it smaller or bigger than the reference. if you are doing the art digitally and only have 1 monitor, I recommend printing it out, I think a library charges like 5-25 cents for a number of pints, you can also get a print service online the barge plate book printed single sides would be about 21$ from a quick google search, if you don't have a printer, or if your printer cant handle images (brother black and white laser I have shits the bed on images, but fantastic for text as an example)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6438243
here I found this one

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GZm7qih71-w

it's not exactly perfect, they are using a cross for a plumb line instead of just 1 line, but its also not a complete grid, and he calls out at a point in the video that you shouldn't grind it. this should give you a good idea of what you are going to be going for.

the idea isnt speed, its more about proportion and being able to observe, personally, and in all honesty the stage that you are at, proportion is FAR more important, so you would essentially just want to contour the pieces and map shadows.

shadow mapping, at least its the term I learned it with, is where you treat the edge of the darkest light and the lightest dark as a contour, rather than rendering out the shadow out, a lot of the bargue plates have shadow maps on them so look through them and you will likely see a few, I think the first one on my pdf is page 32, the first foot the middle image, I think "plate 1, 5" if your source is not great

this should help quite alot.

to be honest, at that point its more or less paint by numbers based on observational skills, the main how to do it and what to do is already talked about and shown.

for the simplified ones, I believe those are examples of what you should come out with, not so much something to copy

If you know the concept of blocking something in, that's kind of what this is, with you going off that and rending out over time, these aren't really meant to be fast exercises, but ones that stress observation and proportional measurements, granted with time comes speed, with knowledge comes ways to simplify.

for overlaying, yea, that's what I would do, irl or in program, pic 2 points and plumbline the plate, make it smaller or larger than what you are going to do, and then match up later on those two points and see how close you are.

posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

if you haven't tried the memorization technique, now would be a good time to try it, especially if you're going for simpler studies like for the features.

Make a study
Put away the reference / previous drawing
Draw it again

This will really help the shapes you are studying in Morpho come out in your imaginative drawing

>>6378026
I have the opposite problem, I took a painting class years ago and can only fix things or add detail by reshaping blobs of "paint". My skills have degraded from absence and I'm playing catchup, but my eyes are still ok. I'd like some help on that, but for your problem:

Usually a person has a preference for what kind of style of painting they want, even if they aren't consciously thinking about a certain era of painting. Here are some things to keep in mind while painting:
Do you like it when it looks like you painted it, or do you want to hide it?
Are little details fun or annoying? How about highlights?
There are many ways to make a focal point, which way do you like?

And when you've figured this out, you bend more towards that direction. Since this is the master study thread, you eyeball the art movements on wikipedia or something and say, "that one". For example, someone who doesn't enjoy painstaking detail and wants a painterly look, but likes little flourishes may study impressionist artists.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6385906
I know this was posted a while ago but given how complicated the original seems to be, how did you go about starting this study? I still stumble over my own feet when doing master studies of complex work

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6400090
spend quite some time doing line art
then paint all the big shape first squint my eyes till it has similar value and color contrast (since I don't try to make it the exact color from the rei one)
when both are done the rest is just mindless zooming in and filling/rendering all the small stuff following the line while zooming out to double-check the big picture with rei one
then paint over the line and redraw some of it
notice that rei is using a different technique here with clean line art and sticking to it so the edge is cleaner and can change line art color a lot. which is hard for me to do since the ref is kinda blurry and I'm lazy so I draw loosely then paint over and redraw some of the line art

i got a question
does a master study need to be a 1:1 copy of the subject?
sometimes it irks and disappoint me in the end when i noticed my whole piece is different from the subject, especially when i notice some lines doesnt match, the angle is off, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6427376
It feels really pedantic at first but you need be able to copy things exactly. When other artists do something successfully, the copying skill will let you figure out how to do it for yourself, so it unlocks a lot of learning to be able to do it right. You are already starting to get the even more important thing though, which is that exact copying forces you to develop your ability to see.

>>6431161
Oh it just looks sort of blocky like the Bridgman figures. You have the right idea in schematizing the block in but it needs to be a little more accurate. The values also look like they're done visually despite the planarization, so the dimensionality gets reduced. Speaking of values, this is a total pain but you should try to clean them up more. Literally sharpen your pencil to the finest point you can and fill in the little white dots on the paper, then go in with a kneaded eraser and pick out all the spots that are too dark. It'll be a huge pain in the ass but it will make your shadows especially look way flatter and give much more the illusion of depth, reality, and completeness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434940
I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

Me personally cant grow by my own anymore as Im shadowbanned. I draw nsfw, not hardcore stuff though, just nudes. Everytime I post something new, my tweet gets hidden for at least 12 hours. It isnt showing in the search option, not by keywords, neither tags. I rely just on my own followers and luck. And even my own followers dont see my posts most of the time. I have 3k, but only getting 30 likes or so because of this. The moment another account RTs me, I can reach 3k likes. Thats really awful and discouraging.

I wish there were other places for promote yourself instead of depending 100% on that.

Whitout tracing what do younthink is the best way to paint from a digital image that you create/control (AI or not).
Should you upscale it to fit your canvase or just work from the original reference. Has anyone here tried projecting onto a canvas and then painting?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434502
You have to fudge the dimensions since all the images are squares, but that’s not too tough. I find it’s better not to do an underdrawing since a lot of the aspects of each AI image are kind of nonsense. So I find the most success with painting directly onto an undercoated painting. Like really the best way to make the AI images into paintings is to heavily HEAVILY draw with the paint. It’s almost similar to plein air painting if you’ve done some of that. You homogenize details in a similar fashion. I’d say if you want to get better at translating the AI images into oil paintings next summer you should get out and do some plein air work. That’s how I feel doing them, it’s not necessarily useful painting from photos to practice for them since the AI is never as precise as a photo

posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

Previous thread: >>6403987

posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Other open comic publishers:

Dark Horse ( https://www.darkhorse.com )
>Dark Horse still welcomes your submissions, and all submissions will still be reviewed, just as they always have been.
>All unsolicited story/series proposals must have a full creative team on board. Writer-only proposals will not be reviewed.

Image comics ( https://imagecomics.com/ )
>Image Comics only publishes creator-owned material. They do not contract creators; they’re only interested in publishing original content for which you would retain all rights.
>Image Comics publishes creator-owned/creator-generated properties and THEY DON’T PAY PAGE RATES. Image takes a small flat fee off the books published, and it will be the responsibility of the creators to determine the division of the remaining pay between their creative team members.

Drawn and quarterly ( https://drawnandquarterly.com/ )
>Please email a low resolution PDF with at least 20 pages of comics and cover letter to submissions. Do not send dropbox links, scripts, or proposals. Please read our submissions FAQ.

Fantagraphics ( https://www.fantagraphics.com/ )
>submission page: https://www.fantagraphics.com/pages/faq

Top Shelf Productions ( https://www.topshelfcomix.com/ )
>Regarding submissions, we're easy. Just email us a download link of what you'd like us to review. NOTE: We cannot accept cover letters, plot synopses, or scripts unless they are accompanied by a minimum of 10-20 completed pages (i.e., fully inked and lettered comic book pages).

Additional publisher lists:
> https://jasonthibault.com/definitive-list-comic-publisher-submission-guidelines/
> https://writingtipsoasis.com/best-independent-comic-book-publishers/

And a new addition, not technically a publisher, but a new platform to host your manga:

Manga Plus Creators by Shueisha
https://medibang.com/mpc/

posts.com: Hey guys. New to manga making, can anyone tell me what are those streaks of lines coming out of the bottom of the middle panel is? And how do I recreate it in csp?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6437063
Those are lines. That they drew, with a pen.
>And how do I recreate it in csp?
By drawing lines. I'd recommend a ruler. Check out the special rulers, there's some goodies in there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6437063
I'm pretty sure they're meant to represent the shiny floor's reflections and give a sense of the 3D space(the light coming from the balcony and further inside the room around where Shin is being relatively more in shadow), but double compositionally as a sort of "speed line" effect. Most effective comic composition will have physical elements uphold emotional ones.
Most drawing programs will have a parallel ruler. You could probably automate it but stuff like that sticks out like a sore thumb, webtoons are full of pasted-on effects and it makes things look relatively cheap.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6437063
It's just an effect to balance the composition and separate the middle panel from the last two. It isn't realistic, judging by the other reflections that tone doesn't make sense.

You can easily do it in CSP using a radiant ruler or a perspective ruler.

>>6432980
i wouldnt listen to that guy who was trying to give u advice. the hair goes dark enough. the darkness of your shadows depend on the ambient light in the area, which is a lot of light based on the rest of your figure and how dark the shadows go everywhere else. you can darken them, but thats mostly for design purposes, composition, to make shapes WITH the darks. but if thats not what you are going for, then its ok to have shadows that dont go way dpp, your shadows are ok as they look, value wise, unless again, you are trying to make composition with your shadows like i did with my composition sketch here
>>6433103
but the mood of your painting is not like that. lighting determines mood. if you want a serious mood, go for dark shadows, if you are doing cute anime girls, you dont need strong dark shadows and dramatic cast shadows and shit. it looks ok.

to answer your question about the "problem" your having with the hair, unless you articulate it another way i dont see a problem. the most important thing is that the hair looks natural and it fits to the painting, if it didnt fit it would look like it was cut out of a magazine or something. but it works, honestly it looks fine and matches the rest of your painting in terms of lighting, values and brushwork so i wouldnt worry about it. hair DOES get dark, because its reflective, but you went dark enough as far as im concerned.

posts.com:
>draw from a reference with heavy perspective
>take a pic of my drawing, overlay it on the reference, see it's off
>realize that i have the paper tilted relative to my body so the angles i'm seeing and the angles i'm drawing are off
>throw out page, take 2 with more angle checking and paying attention to the paper orientation
>feel that it's better, take a pic to check again which is in pic related
>it's off again
i've been free handing all of the lines which hasn't been helping but i'm getting filtered by trying really hard to have good accuracy, feeling good when i draw it, then seeing i'm way off which really destroys my motivation to keep drawing. i do a bunch of simple studies and never anything like an entire room put together so i wanted this to be a study of a complete room but i feel like this is too much at once for a /beg/ like myself

>>6436995
I spend like an hour trying to fiddle with it, but I didn't like it. Most of the issues that I struggled with were the composition, it's an interesting idea, but the elements are placed awkwardly and the framing of the door and the character around this creature don't add much to the overall image.
Also I'd suggest doing some sketching of the creature itself in different views, I couldn't make sense of the how is the pelt placed on the robe, maybe just wrapping it around the neck and shoulder would work. Also the arms and overall pose of the creature have a weird read, it's both perspective and pose to be honest, I'd advice drawing the overall structure before even rendering it, thinking about the creature size and it's relationship with other elements should be a priority as well.
The christmas tree is interesting and detailed but next to the creature is competing for the attention, as it's an overcast setting it becomes hard to balance things out but a cheap trick is lowering the saturation on less important elements.
Those snowflakes and other photoshop effects bring down the quality of the image, I'd remove them. The silhouette of that character could be a kid, but I'd still make it bigger, it doesn't add much to the image atm.
Overall it has nice ideas, the background, the tree, the brushes and texturing in those looks decent, but it's affected by the composition itself and doesn't mesh well in some areas, practice your composition with small thumbnails, that way you don't commit and avoid spending hours trying to salvage it, look at movies frames for inspo.
One last thing, think about the mood or what you want people to feel from your image, I don't know if it's intending to be horror or just mysterious or strange, but I don't feel in any particular way about it. See paintings related to the themes you want to have as reference, it could help, overcast settings are kind of hard to do so there's nothing wrong with using direct reference for it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6437428
You know how you get better at Chess? You play long games where you have the opportunity to think deeply, and then spend hours analyzing each of those games to find your mistakes. This will naturally make your blitz chess better, even though you aren't directly training speed. The reverse is not true, and it's the same with drawing. Taking 3+ hours to work on a study should be the norm, not a sign of weakness. Some of my best studies from the last year I would say took between 20-40 hours. Once you learn how to work deeply, your quicker gestural work will naturally improve.

posts.com:
>>6437509
Yes, is generally adviced not to have your focal elements on the center, it just makes everything feel disjointed.
Watch this video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rYOox8E8ohc&ab_channel=MarcoBucci
It's important you figure your elements in the painting as much as how the light is gonna play out, if it's something nice or wholesome, the kind of thing you'd see in a children's book, then you may want to have some warms in there, obviously an overcast scene is gonna prove difficult to give you that, so you either fake a light source, or make it night time and enhace that warm. There are ways to make an overcast scene look cozy, like a clean composition. I think >>6437377 is a safe way to go, and definitely having the character next to the door cutting that boring 90 degree angle is interesting enough to lead the eye between the two elements interacting. Yours right now is a bit strange because the hand in the other side makes for some impossible anatomy on the character between the door frame and the door with the person.
I'd play with the pose of the creature a little bit more and point it's face towards the person at the door, if it was holding something or doing some sort of playful gesture that'd be a nice addition as well, find reference for cheering or singing poses.
I'd also advice looking at Devin Korwin's Creative Fundamentals Vol.1, it's a PDF file and you can find it in a book thread around here, it deals with some fundamentals knowledge artists should have even before painting anything.

posts.com:
>>6437680
Just forgot to mention, remember you can play with your canvas size and ratio, it's very common for artisits to use the standard A4 canvas size vertical/horizontal but there are more options, this will directly affect your overall composition in terms of what you can or can't do within your limited space (more on that on Devin's book), it's worth to keep an eye out for that, it will flex your composition muscle. Also keep an eye for perspective, the horizon line and the angle of your camera "shot", as previously mentioned movies deal with this and provide some masterfully execution that's very valuable to study as an artist (google "FilmGrab"just look out for good movies and shows, even animation, there's an overlap as you may have noticed), as for a YouTube channel, Moderdayjames is a good place to learn from, Perspective Made Easy book is a friendly introduction as well, and Marshal Vandruff's 1994 course should have you covered on the basics.
Good luck and Merry Christmas to you too anon.

>>6432628
correa art mostly for his paint mixing and pallet control. i think im more impressed by how he works his paint than any of hte actual paintings.

stay creative painting with ryan o'rourke is really good to follow along with and learn. i dont really watch now that ive learned to paint, but it was by far the best youtube channel for learning acrylic painting, mixing paint, and, most importantly, how much fucking water you need to do anything. if you struggle with painting, you probably dont use enough water. most do speed paint no commentary. he has hours long videos step by step explaining exact brush, showing how much water, how to mix the paint by parts (1 part white, 1 part red, 2 parts blue, etc) and how that helps you make bigger amount or recreate the color or how to go from the one color to a lighter one or bring back contrast, etc as you are trying to match a color. very informative and well worth doing some paint alongs if you want to get into it.

bradwynn jones seems to have given up on his channel, but the videos are still there. if you struggle with drawing portraits or loomis, he is a godsend. youll learn so much from following along. has loomis plate videos, but usually just uses a pintrest/instagram portrait and draws from that reference. combines loomis with reilly rhythms and explains every step hes making, how he measures relative distances and how they relate back to loomis or reilly or basic anatomy. goes from construction to finished lines to rendering for most videos. another well worth checking out if you want to learn to draw using these techniques.

richard friend is comic book inker and arguably one of the best. from a time when it was skill based and not just digital tracing of tumblr artists at marvel and dc that they have today. he mostly does art books and creator spotlights for his favorite artists. go to archives and he has insanely good inking tutorials for brush, quill, etc.

>>6423332
Instead of taking a course, do the following every day for a week:

Write down a list of at least 5 things you like. Does not have to be only artists, can be media of any sort, or hell even odd shit like food if you want.

Make a venn diagram. Label it with one of the 5 subjects.
Write what you want to learn from the subject, artwise, in the middle
Write what you already can do as good or better than the subject in the left
Write what you don't like/care about the subject in the right.

Repeat for each of the daily 5.

---

It's an exercise for self-awareness and understanding your influences and where you want your directions to go. When you have done all these you can then use that knowledge to know what you wanna study from the different subjects. Character design is downstream from that stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6436845
This isn't a comment I got but these 2 characters I've been fleshing out for a comic for years, ended up getting "copied" by 2 big name cartoon shows like 4 years after I imagined them myself. It pissed me off at first, but I didn't let it get to me. I resolved instead to adjust my characters and their narrative world in a way that mogs those cartoons(in my opinion,) and makes my characters even more distinctly my own. I'll never get famous from it and retards might still try to compare my characters (which came first) to the characters from the cartoons, or even some unpredictable media I've never heard of. But I'll never doubt myself about it and that's what matters. My creations have a life of their own, it's my job to convince people to see them as distinct, and hell it might even be fun to lean into some of the comparisons for laughs. If you aren't fighting tooth and nail to carve out your own identity through your creations you're just too weak.

>>6438205
You still have 3D art and animations.
>But AI can already do 3D models
Yes, and they are all just horseshit blobs that dont look anything like what you asked it for, and their methods of creating these blobs is heavily unreliable for any high quality models with multiple layers. All they do is literally just make 3 pictures of thing from imagegen, then they use those images to photoscan the object and then deliver you your shitty model. You know how imagegens suck at making the same thing 2 times in a row, it will take at least half a year to perfect this, which would basically also mean that videos are now fully possible to make at high quality with no interpolation needed. How will you tell the AI that some parts of the object have multiple parts? You wont by current metrics.

Also, dont forget that while pictures only require you to put pixels on the roughly correct places to be fully passable, 3D objects cannot just be shapes with texture. Maybe for static background objects, but not for animated characters. You need to give the model good topology, which is low skill technical thing you can only manage to make if you make the object by hand from simple geometry (kinda like if you had to force artbot to replicate manually all the brushstrokes instead of just making it denoise stuff and find patterns). You will then also have to rig the model, which is already kinda possible in humanoid models, but to rig dinosaur properly will probably take some time to figure out. Then you will have to give it proper drivers and shape keys for good animations, and finally animate it. Animating humanoids with words will be possible next year thanks to there being lot of data on it, but animating alien octopus with swords for tentacles will be near impossible since there is no training data for this. Which brings me to final point, there is virtually no data on 3D models.

Also, there are at least 20 different professions at higher risk of automation then 3D artists.

>>6438233
2-10 years. It is really really hard to predict where we are now. Right now the 3D modelling AI is about in the same stage where image AI was in 2017 when anons made these old threads posted here. 3D models have way less data, but at the same time the amount of money being put inside of AI research now and before is incomparable. AI has shown that it works and it is really impressive, and that it is not just a dumb fad like crypto. When you explain AI, it ranges from research with limitaded use, to something that is so effective it makes people around you shiver in fear. Crypto on the other hand is either horribly ineffective ponzi scheme, or horribly ineffective way of doing transactions, since their decentralized nature makes their transaction consume something like 2000 or whatever times more power. My pain point however should not be to think about how long it will take for 3D models to be automated, but rather how many jobs will be automated beforehand.

Once chatbots learn how to make really really long texts to replace writers, they will also replace many other professions. AI still cannot replace technical artists. Speculative evolution? Scientific artwork like cryptozoology and microorganism artwork? Intriquate sci fi? Fantasy with historical references? All it can do now is either make something already existing, or make cool looking designs. This is the main flaw of the current methods, and these methods are several years old. To get rid of these methods, you would either need to give the user far more control over the AI, which then artists will be the ones best suited for using it (unlike prompts where the main skill is testing prompts, weights and remembering artist names), or you will need to also automate the scientists and historians themselves, at which point you will basically have AGI, since AI that can critically think and find solutions to any kind of problem is also able to collect its own data and invent its own learning methods

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6415721
>>6416200
I start off either with a bean or a trapezoid for the torso and turn it into a precise and coherent 3d shape. Then I add flat shapes for neck and limbs and slowly work myself through carefully connecting them with bracketing and flesh them out afterwards. It takes a little longer that way, but in the end it's 15 times faster because I don't have to do endless corrections afterwards. What's great about it is it finally lets me control the bendyness of the torso like I want to, and having a clear direction where the arms are in 3d space. Here's my practice sheet from today exploring a little more.

>>6424335
You're getting conflicting advice. I'm doing bridgman copies from memory rn. Here's my two cents, and I'm posting my work (bridgman from memory). If I'm contradicted by a better artist, so be it.
>stop doing timed exercises
These are not useful for a beginner. Do it right before you do it fast.
>roughly learn the proportions of the human body
You don't have to learn every last detail but from your sketches you're having huge issues with proportion. Learn the chart for a male and female standing, 7.5 or 8 heads tall (bridgman uses 7.5, that's what I go with). Be able to draw it from memory, use graph paper if you have to. Again, just get a rough idea, since figure drawings will often be in perspective or bent etc. But if you don't even know how long the legs are supposed to be in relation to the torso, that will reflect in your work, so get a hold of that.
>Michael Hampton's Figure Drawing: Design and Invention
Read the chapter, copy the sketches in that chapter, reproduce the sketches from memory, then try some on your own from photo reference. GOOD photo reference, not porn or social media selfies. Do a lot of standing poses that emphasize contrapposto so you get a good feel for weight. Don't neglect feet, ground your figures. Don't worry about hugely foreshortened figures or sitting/lying figures for now, just internalize the idea of the spine and weight-bearing leg.
>Pit stop: boxes and cylinders
After doing the gesture chapter of Micky Hamps, before you move on, make sure you're somewhat comfortable with drawing boxes and cylinders in perspective. You don't have to be Erik Olsen, but get a good feel for it as well as wrapping simple solids and organic forms with cross-contour lines as well.
cont...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6429943
>Finish mickey hamps's book
Keep going through the book by reading the chapter, copying the sketches, reproducing them from memory, and then trying them from GOOD photo reference. Supplement your anatomical knowledge with a good anatomy book. Goldfinger, Morpho, Stonehouse, Anatomy for Sculptors, doesn't really matter just pick one. I like morpho because it's small and the "willowy" morpho figures complement Bridgman's boxier, stouter ones later on.
>Bridgmarathon
Now it's time for the big boy: copy bridgman twice (skipping the heads section) just like Daddy Finch told you. Since I'm here I won't go any farther than this, but my plan after finishing Bridgman is to brush up on my portraiture by doing the "copy twice" method with Loomis' faces book.

>>6437970
There's also a billion digital artists, and not very many traditional anymore. The bigger presence is part of how digital artists get drowned out by the constant influx of new artists, and the entrenched famous ones. Traditional at this point in time, with online sales, is as close to a true meritocracy as you can get. You make a great painting, it will sell. No such guarantee exists for a great digital artwork. If you have no followers nobody sees it. If you list a great painting on Etsy, people see it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6437982
>Correct me if I am wrong
You're wrong. Anyone can list an artwork on Etsy or eBay and set the price for it. If it doesn't sell you need to put your ego aside and figure out what to do for the next one to make it sell. Another great benefit of these online marketplaces is that those "bad" paintings don't go anywhere. You can keep them listed forever if you feel like it (Although I regularly cull my offerings to make them only the best ones). The challenge then becomes say you sold a painting for $300, but it was your best painting and none of the other ones are selling. That's where it becomes a job, and it separates the amateurs from the professional artists. Are you willing to do 50 more paintings in the next two months to get 3 more sales of $300? Now you have 47 paintings that haven't sold. Do you go back and make those better and try again to sell them? Do you make 50 more? How do you budget the $1200 you made to afford supplies and shipping materials? These are all things I've dealt with and overcome at the moment but are constant things I have to keep in mind with every painting I make.

With digital you do none of this. You can labor away on your digital art for the rest of your life and never make a penny and it'll never force you to improve or learn how to sell your work.

>>6435234
The writing style.

Japanese, Chinese, Korean, and to some extent Thai all require you learn much more comprehensive pen control than other writing systems in order to be legible at all. Even with computers it's required that you learn how to write properly.

I used some katakana and hiragana as practice for a few weeks earlier this year. I don't know how to read/write in japanese still, but it was great pen control practice to just grind drawing 1 character a day and fill a page. My skill notibly improved vs drawing just shapes, in part because I had to continually adjust for the specific kana to look correct.

I suspect it's a combination of a few things
>more aznz = more masters
like you said
>grindset
Competition for schools in japan, korea, parts of china is fierce, which engenders a mentality of "you have to be the best." Hence tiger moms. Asian culture doesn't repudiate hardcore grinding.
>Kanji
I unironically believe that kanji has something to do with it. If you've ever tried to learn kanji you'll notice it feels a lot like doing (really simple) bargue copies, lots of memorizing angles, shape language, etc.
>Art education
Early art education in the West is a complete joke, you fingerpaint as a kid and you show up to art class in high school and as long as you have a pulse you get an A. You do some crappy still lifes and call it a day. Not sure how it works in Asia but I don't see how it could be worse.
>Manga culture and copying
For some reason people in the West are afraid to copy. Thankfully that seems to be changing, but in asia it's pretty much accepted that if you want to learn to draw you copy manga you like. Notice how all the good western comic book artists got their start by copying their favorite superhero comics.

anyway, that's my hypothesis, pulled completely from my ass. be sure to like and subscribe

>>6413837
So Copic itself is a brand. I'm not sure if it's the OG alcohol based brush marker, but it's basically the standard. I would have recommended Prismacolor last year if you didn't want to splurge on Copics, but I think they're discontinuing the line since I've been seeing them on major clearance at every art store. With that being said, you could easily get a good deal. I personally prefer Copics over all of the alternate brands (Ohuhu is my least favorite and I think they give Instagram/YouTube artists free sets for the good reviews because they kinda suck in person). If you want new, you can buy them for cheapest on Blick. After Christmas, you'll see a lot of sets for sale on sites like Mercari and that's where I got mine for a really good deal. I like that Copics are refillable, and they get a lot cheaper to use when you're refilling them. Other good Copic alternate brands I like are Kuretake and Tombow (make sure not to accidentally get their water markers). Hope this helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6423644
read 'drawing lessons from the great masters' by robert beverly hale.
practice drawing cylinders and spheres until you can draw them in such a way that they're so good they look like an optical illusion. drawing cubes is to condition your mind for perspective so you should do that as well. by practicing these shapes, your paintings will take on their nature. as an example; if you drill proficiency of spheres into your artistic ability, you will be automatically better at drawing breasts.
the book i mentioned will teach you the fundamentals so that you are well-quipped to navigate the various aspects of art. it moreso teaches you how to think like an artist, rather than simply telling you what to think.
you can already do hands better than ai so at least you've got that going for you.

Traditional gouache was never meant to be archival, it doesn't form a film once it dries, it's chalky and gets dirty fast unless you put it under glass, it's was meant for illustrators to quickly turn their artwork, photograph it for publishing and forget about it.
General speaking you should worry about the pinks but there are colors that people not suspect like raw sienna and yellow ochre, they will get grayer, unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Even acrylic will shift, I have Golden Fluid Yellow Ochre and it shifted to gray months later. Any color that looks saturated and vibrant won't stay that way for long.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6367918
>Is artist grade Gouache worth it?
Yes. You'll get more pigment, smoother grind, better flow, single-pigment colours (better mixing), less fillers (more vibrant). Schmincke is great, and I can wholly recommend. Just get a few tubes of artist-grade instead of a bunch of chinesium.

>I also want to start painting with acrylic. Do it need any special medium like oil paint or just apply directly on canvas?
Water-soluble, so thinning with water works. You'll only need mediums if you want to thin it a ton, since super-thinned paint films are not necessarily durable. Other than that you can pretty much paint on anything. It's essentially coloured plastic.

There's like a million mediums that you won't need but that could be nice, like thickeners, thinners, drying time extenders, crackling, more shine, less shine, flow improvers, etc. You can make a frankenpaint to your specific liking if you really want to tinker with it.

>>6368450
As said in last thread, Mont Marte probably does not manufacture their own stuff and commission random (see: cheapest) manufacturer to make stuff they just repackage. Sometimes you can get decent stuff, but it really is playing art supply gacha.

HIMI Jelly Gouache is significantly better, and honestly a pretty decent quality paint. I would recommend Holbein, if that's available in your neck of the woods.

>>6368722
>unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Holbein, WN, Schmincke Horadam, and M. Graham all make Gouache without the addition of whiteners, relying on pure pigment density to get opacity. Any of these will work. It's notable that Holbein is by far the cheapest, at least in EU, and Schmincke pigment is very finely ground so it's less opaque than the others.
