posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6372118
chalk/marble dust (can extend pigments in oil; use for making paint transparent for glazing in oil; traditional glue chalk ground is less expensive than ready-made acrylic ground and dry components store longer; use as opacifier in gouache)
rabbit skin glue/hide glue (used for grounds, sizing; distemper medium; glue for attaching canvas to board)
metal point (small piece lasts very long; brass can be found for free, or buy/find wire that lasts many life times over; some can fit into a clutch pencil; can coat scrap wood with chalk and or some other ground of your choice in weak glue size and reuse board for scrap drawings, by recoating or scraping)
charcoal powder (can be made for free; decent for ink with suitable binder ground finely; good for paint; use for tracing; many other uses)
egg (yolk and pigment for egg tempera, good for lean underpainting for oil paint or as a cheap and durable paint, don't need entire yolk; can make water-miscible paint by adding to oil paint, thin and clean with water instead of solvents; glair, made by whipping egg white and letting liquid separate from foam, can be used as paint or ink binder; adjust strength with distilled water; can be dried by pouring in a shallow container and letting sit, dissolve again by water; supposedly aged wet, not too tightly sealed glair is better; can be modified by adding honey or sugar etc; used in some varnish recipes; can be use in metal point grounds)

>>6372834
None if you use inks, if not then the film isn't strong enough to adhere to the other layers, should be fine if you're just staining the paper. Use gesso, it will create blooms like watercolor.

Too much water will upset the balance and spread the acrylic polymer too thinly so the molecules can't reconnect properly to form a stable film. Instead you should dilute with an acrylic medium, which is essentially the same as the paint but without the color pigment.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6375078
if lead is only a trace element in zinc, imagine how little is in titanium wtth 2-5% zinc. painting with cadmium colors is so much more dangerous at that point.
there's a number of inert pigments that are mostly transparent in the average layer of oil paint you can add to make any pigment more transparent.
calcium carbonate (chalk, egg shells, marble, limestone), silica (crushed glass, pumice, silica-rich sand, quartz). calcium carbonate is safer because silica can damage lungs much more. make a paint mixing the transparent pigment with oil to a consistency you like and add it to your tube paint, or add chalk directly and add oil if it is too lean.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375089
>By the way, just HOW dangerous is Lead white if you don't grind it yourself? For example are you in trouble if you get it on your skin while painting?
Not in quantities you'd use if it happens a couple of times, but over time you could get yourself in trouble. Lead doesn't really leave your body basically ever once it gets in. By itself, anyway: you can get rid of most of it with Dimercaprol.

If you get it in your food somehow, either by having it in your fingers (Even if it's so little as to not show clearly) or clothes or whatever, that's actually bad. That's why it's recommended to use gloves (Nitrile only: Latex can get dissolved by oil/solvents) and to never eat/drink while in the studio if working with lead white.

Mostly it's a case of "better safe than sorry", but there's genuine long-term health risks that many underestimate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whats the difference between using linseed oil vs paint thinner for thinning oil paints?
Everything I can find online seems to talk about them interchangeably, is there a reason to use one over the other?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6390809
+linseed oil makes the paint have more oil (oil to pigment ratio increases) slower drying, more gloss, not as easy to paint over dry, harder for atmospheric vapors and moisture to penetrate, more yellowing, more flexible, used for glazes
+paint thinner makes makes the oil thinner (oil to pigment ratio remains the same but effectively lower since it also breaks down oil) leaner and thinner paint layer, more matte surface, pigment can be unbound if thinned too much, more susceptible to dirt and moisture penetration due to microscopic pores, faster drying, mostly used for under layers

In general you can get very dark tones in watercolour, but those are usually synthetic pigments or mixes of two or more pigments that cancel each other out.
Or straight up black paint, but that's generally a bad idea in my experience.

>>6394737
it's not an alternative to thinners. it's more of an alternative to fluid and gel mediums like sunthickened linseed oil or maroger medium. while thinners lower the oil content, fluid and gel mediums increase the oil content.
one should not use too much thinner because pigments lose binder.
one should not use too much fluid/gel medium because the pigments have too much binder and can cause problems like wrinkling or yellowing depending on the medium.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6399981
G pen is good option if you don't like fineliner. Maru nibs is an option for thinner lines. Dip pen need a lot of practice and kinda messy at first. Stick with Japanese brands.
Also try to use brush and ink, the only problem is they can't really use waterproof ink, otherwise it's pretty flexible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6399981
Brushes and brush pens can be a bit difficult to get used to since you feel much less contact with the surface, but they're a lot of fun. Definitely the most versatile mark-making wise, but it takes a bit of practice to be able to do very fine detail work with them.
Pic related is great since you can control how much ink is loaded on it for drybrush effects and stuff, unlike the Pentel Pocket Brush which is always wet (which makes it a bit more difficult to handle, too).
Dip pens aren't bad choices either, but they also take some getting used to. Just wanted to mention brushes since I feel like they're a bit overlooked these days which is a shame.
Waterproof ink gives brushes a shorter lifespan, but it's not that big of a deal. Pen nibs break and brushes eventually lose their point, but you'll still probably go through them much slower than fineliners.

>>6404987
to clarify
i wasn't talking about watercolor. i meant that even for drawings in dry media i only use pure cotton paper, (but not watercolor cotton paper.) if you explain to buyers of watercolor that something is made of cotton, that's simply expected, especially if the buyer has been in the market for buying watercolor works.
i go beyond what is expected when it comes to materials. for oil painting, the standard is simply to use tube paints, with titanium as the white, over acrylic gesso. i grind from dry pigments, use the best lead white available, and use lead oil ground with the same lead white.
it's not merely an issue of the work fading or deteriorating in 10 years or in their lifetime either. as there are practices and materials that i admit are more archival, but are simply not as beautiful, prestigious, or expensive. aluminum panels, mdf, and plywood are very stable, but are not as inspiring as a joined solid wood panel with hand cut butterfly keys. when it comes to works of art, i consider the support as part of the art, so they must be beautiful as well.
or some materials might outlast others in a few hundred years, but the more available materials are good enough.

there are illustrations of both in use or separately.
palette is good for mixing various tones and making the range of movement more efficient in painting. it also means the paint is somewhat more paste-like. mixtures from the paste can be thinned down with water or more medium, or painted dry thinly. i notice that palettes were generally smaller, because the mixes were simpler and they painted differently colored parts separately, and that the familiar kidney shaped palette became more common later.
shells and bowls are good for fluid paints. the ribs of the shells or the rim of the bowl makes it easy to remove excess moisture from the brush. the bowl shape also means that moisture evaporates slower. one can make different mixes in separate shells but this can be wasteful since you often only need a small amount of each especially since tempera is painted very thinly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6415075

The sets are bad, you're paying a lot for hues that don't play well together.

Only get the SKETCH markers, not the Classic or Ciao. Start with a cool/neutral/warm gray set depending on your style and needs, they can be used as a base with other hues.

Then buy a set of singles with similar color intensities and ID's. Check this guide to make sense of the ID system: https://markernovice.com/copic/copic-numbering

If you're going for realism you're not going to want all the intense candy shades, plus that the hue samples usually look lighter than they'll end up on your paper/pad after several strokes, and a lot of the really lighter shades (X000 etc) can be used to mix with other hues for great effect.

So for a range of blues you might want B21 Baby Blue, B91 Night Blue, B37 Antwerp Blue, B61 Light Hydrangea, instead of the intense ones like B29 Ultramarine, B16 Caynine Blue or B06 Peacock Blue. You can easily get by with a set of 3-4 in each hue range, some skintones, some ultralights, which might amount to 20 or so markers total. A lot cheaper than 72 goofball hues that don't blend well.

You'll get a blender with a gray set but it's not what you think, blending is done by carefully connecting two adjacent hues and not with the blender marker, it's more of an FX thing that'll wet your strokes and turn them abit watercolory.

>>6426165
For dry drawing media, I use a silver point. My favorite surface is fine Carrara marble dust that is mixed with Dutch lead white which has been ground in vinegar and washed, sometimes tinted with other pigments. For darker lines, some pumice or quartz. For the glue, I choose parchment size mixed with a solution of potash alum.
For the ink to use with natural quill, I take the shavings of red sandalwood or brazilwood and heat it gently in well water, which afterwards is mixed with gum arabic and a pinch of potash alum. I add a drop of clove oil as a preservative.

posts.com:
>>6428703
I can't see any of those videos, only the thumbnails because I don't have an Instagram account, but it looks like he uses a fair bit of line weight.
Fineliners are alright and very straightforward for a beginner to use since they always have a single constant width but they won't get you natural line variation, you'll need to manually thicken the line by drawing over it. Their lines can feel very mechanical otherwise, which is only natural considering they're like a disposable version of technical drawing pens.
Fineliners don't shatter under your hand or anything, but they tend to be inconsistent and start having ink flow problems with time, requiring you to hold them very vertically to keep working. The problem is compounded if you happen to be heavy-handed, so if you think that might end up a problem it might be a good idea to pick up Uni-pins instead since they have very durable tips.
But Microns are perfectly well-loved pens as far as their type goes. If you're in for even and consistent lines it's what fineliners will give you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428775
Mangaka mainly use dip pens (pic rel), but they're difficult to control and can be a bit hard to find. Bristle brush pens and proper brushes have the most line variation and they're what's behind most of those 熱血 crazy-looking thick lines in drawings by animators like Umakoshi and Hayama. They're also very difficult to control. The difficulty can be a good thing if you want to challenge yourself and train your dexterity, but it could get frustrating for a beginner.
Felt tip brush pens are comparatively really easy to control and you can still get good line variety out of them. I've never used the Micron one but it's probably fine.
A lot of manga artists do use fineliners, but it's usually for details, hatching or speech bubbles. Maru nibs produce similarly thin lines, but they can thicken a bit if you press harder. You can still get super delicate lines out of a pen or brush if you're skilled enough, Akihito Yoshitomi does a lot of detailed machine drawings with dip pens on YouTube if you're interested in watching someone ink in real time.
That's not to say nobody ever inks mainly with fineliners, and I think they were common in shoujo manga in the 2000s. They're very popular with people who draw anime-style illustrations on social media and can be very convenient to work with. They eventually worm their way into a lot of people's workflows, so there's no harm getting some experience with them now if you want to. I think with inking it's definitely a matter of trying a lot of things and seeing what suits you.
Whatever you end up with, I hope you have fun, Anon.

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

Not at all. You need to have marks down so you have a point of comparison. Here's a video of one of Krenz's students copying simple line drawings:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iK5Qn_Iwv9A
Accuracy, specially as a beginner, isn't about getting things exactly right the first time, but being patient and correcting things until you do. With time your eye for proportions and relative distances will get better, but even pros have to double-check and correct their initial assumptions from time to time.

As long as you're actually comparing the distances and measuring you'll get something out of it. In real life people have to be more thoughtful about checking since it takes way longer to do, but in both cases comparing with the original is the only way to know if you have the "right answer".
It might be a good idea to only check once you're done with a stage of blocking-in, and then correct as needed until you can move on. If you check after every line or every other line it really would be pretty close to mindless.
Being ambitious is a good attitude, the upper half looks very nice. If you combine accuracy with studying volumetric drawing you can understand the subject better and get more out of artist studies.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6426949
I just mean drawing with 3D volume in mind. The folds on the sleeves, for example, come across as random marks and don't have any form.
Depicting form with only line is very difficult, but things don't suddenly flatten out when they're in frontal or side view. Seeing how others can create the illusion of volume even under those constraints is one of the reasons to do master studies.
Training accuracy is mostly about 2D observations like relative proportion, but if you're studying an image that depicts 3D form you'll miss out on a lot if you don't keep those aspects in mind and analyse them too.

Chicken scratching just means drawing a billion little lines to build up one hard to read, hairy-looking line. This is bad because it makes the drawing confusing even to the person who drew it, and fucks up your perception making it harder to see the form.
Restating a line to refine a shape or guessing what you want your composition or pose to be with light lines before committing to a darker one is regular sketching behaviour and an extremely common way of drawing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't want to seem overly critical, but I feel that the standard way to draw anime is a bit misguided.

Those early animations from which anime is derived were worked on by talented illustrators and painters. But the reason why their output was relatively extremely simplistic wasn't because they didn't desire accurate paintings, but because it would have taken a hundred years to make every frame realistic.

The lineart-and-bucket-fill method was not the desired outcome, but was the most efficient way to drop down shape and definition. If you are not aiming for that one-frame-a-minute pace, I think it would be better to paint your anime, than to draw it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6430997
It's hard to present a thesis when you have a 1000 character limit.

It was merely an observation from doing some research on old animation stuff that the vast majority of anime ever made was made by simplifying a complex subject, outlining the simplification, and filling color inside the lines. This style was a necessity because of time and money constraints, and is the source of "Anime style".

This contrasts with what I've seen recommended for "How to draw Anime", where they tell you to do overly complex style-copying or construction on your favorite anime, when that isn't likely how the original artist made it, or how the original artist would have preferred to make it.

This was not meant to be an attack on others' preferred methods of making art. I just thought it overly complicated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6431107
>This style was a necessity because of time and money constraints, and is the source of "Anime style".
Anime isn't the only medium which does that. Manga, comics, bandes dessinés, etc also do.
This end result doesn't look as such solely due to process behind, it's also due to it being an efficient way to convey meaning and incite emotions in the viewers in an artistic and archetypal manner which can resonate with our brains in way reality/realism cannot, I think. As in, less details isn't entirely about making the work easier, it's also about getting to the essence of things more straightforwardly.

>This contrasts with what I've seen recommended for "How to draw Anime", where they tell you to do overly complex style-copying or construction on your favorite anime, when that isn't likely how the original artist made it, or how the original artist would have preferred to make it.
That's an interesting remark. For that I think we need to study the kind of people who tend to try and replicate things in such a thorough manner and get why they do so.
The original artist doesn't make it as such because it's innate to them, it's what the different parts of their mind end up producing altogether.
For someone trying to copy it stems from them feeling like what they see is what they want to ingrain. It's like a mirror image which mirrors some sort of sum of what they internally value, or getting close to it at least. Such people who are very sensitive to this internal process have a hard time letting lose and drawing something they internally value negatively since the result they see ends up being linked to their self-worth, which is discouraging. So to sprout motivation they end up making these "overly complex style-copying/construction" in order to slowly rewrite this physical habit within themselves in a way which feels good to them.
Eventually they'll be able simplify the construction the more the target style is "achieved" (cont)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6435364
Follow along Gary Meyer or Erik Olson for basic perspective. Draw the sides of the table until all lines intersect. those 2 intersecting points will be your vanishing points. If you draw a straight horizontal line intersecting these points that's your eye level. Like you said, this will take time but studying the underlying fundies will help you understand it faster. This is an example of my work to see what you can do with fundies. Also, I haven't drawn in 3 months if that even matters.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6437301
not sure if i got the expression you intended right since i wasn't sure if those lines were supposed to mark eyelids or eyebrows.
but overall: try to vary your hues and values. blush tends to be more orange than you might think, and a more orange/pinkish/brownish hue also usually works for shadows under the hair.
just try to let go of choosing only one base color and only making it lighter/darker without changing the hue. warmer colors work well for the face, so a brown insterad of black/grey for lineart is very common around skin. same goes for the eyes, they lacked highlights, and i made the lighter areas a bit more magenta than purple so it looks a bit more dynamic...
tldr: more 'extreme' values, more different hues
(i also changed the left eye to fit the face angle more)

since you are doing this with pencil anyway, try laying down the rough shapes with very light pencil lines before you start with the lineart. the krenz method helps with this:https://youtu.be/kbKqIJcIUCw?t=1490
with this done, you can still make changes and check for angles with the finer stuff

I don't want to bother *too* much of that sort of raw grinding but just try to copy the relevant reference art as close as possible while trying to break it down to pieces which I can immediately use for an original drawing. And when the inevitable weird anatomy/perspective etc jumps out then I just try to fix it as I go.

tl;dr I'm not stupid for taking the "Just draw" meme seriously am I? Pic related are few examples of my drawing. I still have a hard time focusing and just end up drawing something new.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: What is truly the best way to learn the fundamentals?
posts.com:
Information is always different and even the wikis aren't clear on this
Is drawabox really the top dog when it comes to learning shapes and 3D space?
What would you recommend for the absolute beginner?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6435044
"Art" is a big box. Are you interested in fine art? Illustration? Animation? Comics? Sculpture? There are different skills that are more or less important depending on what kind of art you want to do, and different artists or teachers will have different plans of instruction. That being said, I think being able to see and copy accurately from observation are skills that will serve you no matter which way your journey takes you. Once you learn how to "steal," you can learn almost any other (visual) art skill just from xeroxing others. So, basically Bargue plates/Krenzing first, then you can move on to whatever other skills are most relevant to what you want to do in art (Loomis/Bridgeman/etc. for figure construction, Robertson for perspective and environments, Alla Prima if you like painting, etc. - you should be able to guide yourself moderately well at this point.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6435107
Drawabox is, imo, a well intentioned trap. Ask about Krenz in /asg/ and just copy a bunch of your favorite anime until you can do it to a very high degree of accuracy. You should be able to flash your eye back and forth between the reference and your drawing and have mistakes in the shapes jump out at you quickly, almost like it's animated. Once you can see and correct mistakes, you can move onto Loomis/Robertson to start posing figures in environments.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6435186
You're right, you do need to think in 3d eventually, but you need the skill to compare shapes accurately first. Also, when you get better at copying shapes, you will start thinking about things like line weight and overlapping forms that will make you realize even thinking very "2d" you are still representing a solid volume, and need to be able to think about how that translates to the picture plane. More 3d thinking will come with rendering/modeling, and once you feel more comfortable with your ability you'll be able to translate the idea to construction/perspective too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6416749
(Clockwise order)
So-bin
Murata
Atmosphere sketchbooks has sketches from I think 3 artists
Settei Dreams has artbooks and storyboards of anime
Horikoshi has sketches
And Inoue Kiyoshirou has an "artbook" which is just the sketches of a hentai he drew.

In the end, you won't find many "artbooks" like the yoshinari one especially of artists' sketches. Mostly finished work which you said you're not looking for.
Also, don't limit to just artbooks, copy directly from manga too.(Which is how most mangakas got good.) since they're basically just clean sketches

Lastly, don't hoard books, I recommend copying front to back 1 at a time before moving onto the next one every single week.
Hope I helped ;)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6416988
Depending on how strong your fundamentals are, it will extend your understanding of them. If you don't know perspective then you can't understand how the artist is playing with perspective. Master studies are typically done to see how a specific artist solved a problem. There is a big difference between how a sculptor solves painting clothing folds and a comic artist and a painter and one or all of them may be compatible with the style you inevitably end up with but you won't know unless you do the studies to begin with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6419129
Beginner because there are significant errors in perspective, anatomy, and line work, and very little attempt at rendering. By significant errors, I mean the following. Perspective: the hat seems to be intended to be circular and viewed from below, and if that is the case, we should see most of the underside, but instead we see most of the top. Anatomy: the left and right hands have different finger widths and the right hand could not grip the pole properly in this position. Also there is no shape to the ankles, and a very long torso and upper legs compared to short lower legs. Line work: the line work is all of the same width and is concentrated in areas of higher detail, making them appear darker even when they are not in shadow. Hatching direction is inconsistent without any obvious reason to change directions in different areas. Rendering: the light seems to be coming from the left according to the fence and the clouds, but the grass casts shadows in the opposite direction - unless those are ripples, which is unclear. Some portions of the character are shaded, while the hands, face, and underside of the hat are not shaded. The transition from light to dark is abrupt in all areas without any form of feathering.

That said, the composition is nice and I like the way that the fishing rod and line bounces the eye back and forth. The face also looks appealing. This is a beginner with potential.

>>6419297
Intermediate. There is still room for technical improvement as always - for example, the position of the feet in the middle left image is unnatural - but the errors aren’t glaring. You have enough mastery of the basics that you no longer have to think so much about anatomy, perspective, etc. and can start to focus on finding your personal style and/or the types of subjects and ideas you want to explore, perhaps via multiple styles. I see an exploration of many styles and subjects here, which is great. If you’re in the concept art field, this is a decent portfolio. But each one looks mass produced. Joker smile, big boobs, etc. If you want to rise above being a decently hirable concept artist in a very competitive market, push for more originality and more depth to your subject matter. Also, keep working your technical details.

posts.sub: Bad, poorly produced, unfinished art is the future
posts.com:
Pic related: the haters watching as the intentionally incorrectly painted unfinished memes I made 5 years ago become increasingly more interesting to art critics as AI art learns to replicate everything about art but unpredictable human mental illness and laziness.

Everything that I anticipated happening in the next decade starting in 2015 has happened. None of this should be a surprise. We are in an internet dark age. All your digital-only art that shared on some servers in California will not exist in 1000 years.

If you haven’t been investing in arbitrarily doing things wrong on practical paintings that you can hoard and leaving everything unfinished you’re a cuck to Big Robot. Prove me wrong.

The future of “prove you’re a human” is making obvious mistakes and doing things wrong out of spite for stupid and fundamentally self-destructive reasons.

It’s like how the invention of cameras led to impressionism and abstraction and non-objective. The invention of AI will lead to proving that you so arbitrary and unpredictable and lazy and crazy that it’s impossible for a efficiency-driven machine to recreate what you’re doing. The less possible it is for YOU to recreate whatever the fuck you did, the better.

How does one learn to make a loose sketch? I have yet to encounter a resource that really explains any sort of sketching, or even the concept of going from a rough drawing towards a more finished one (beyond a few that have said "this is a thing artists do" but offered no further explanation.) Everything I've read has instead been focused on accuracy and twenty different ways to measure, and how to treat drawing like it was brain surgery. I would really like to find a drawing method that doesn't involve spending 10-15 minutes analyzing a potential line before placing it, which is all that I've learned so far.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434734
Looseness is by it's very nature hard to teach. There isn't just one way to do it. What works for me is drawing very lightly initially, not paying attention to accuracy and proportions. Then I gradually darken the correct lines. It's really hard to explain. Try doing it for a while. Maybe it will click on it's own for you, the way it did for me.

Draw what you have access to from life. For anatomy and portraiture you can use photos. Doing master studies can be one of the most beneficial things for you. It's like you're being taught by the greats themselves.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434782
Like I said it’s mostly things available on my property. I suppose that’s helpful for understanding interiors and nature and the like, but it’s not like drawing a parked lawnmower imparts skills that transfer to drawing alien spacecraft.
By master study, you mean replicate other artwork? I do that already on occasion, I pick random panels from manga, try to mirror it in my head, and then draw that mirrored image on the page. I figure mirroring it helps me understand the lines I’m drawing better, rather than ‘cargo cult’-ing the work. Is that good, or a waste of time?
I’ve heard drawing from photographs isn’t good because you miss out on the dynamism and depth inherent in actual living models.

I’ve wondered how manga artists come to develop their styles. Why is it that kids in Japan naturally draw their cartoons in such a wildly different way? What books do they read, and techniques do they practise? There are millions of ‘self taught’ manga artists who just doodled and it still comes out looking Japanese in a way no western artist replicates fully. even the small things like poses, expressions, wingdings/accents, shading and lighting are distinctly different. I’ve been reading on traditional Japanese philosophy and classical art to try and understand the secret sauce of their society that makes it, but I still feel like I’m nowhere close.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6436963
>when you took a break from competitive games, was it one particular game or all games?
Either or. Sometimes I stop playing and go back to art, sometimes I just stop playing one game for a while.
>Would you circulate games? If so, where these games from similar or different genres?
There's no system but I have a list of games I like from all kinds of genres. The only real rule is if you play a different game to take your break it should have very different gameplay with completely different skill sets.
>How would this correspond to art?
Tunnel vision occurs in games and art. People like me are prone to focusing too hard on perfecting a singular aspect when it's all of the aspects done together that result in success. But being exceptional at all aspects simultaneously is the final stage of mastery. You have to grind your raw aim/form or your movement/proportions individually but when you step away from the grind entirely, then come back to the bigger picture with a clear head, you can apply your new skills without the blindness, tension, and stress, of wanting to get some particular small thing just right. Which causes neglect of other things. I don't know if it's the fastest way to improve but I've made big strides in art and games just by taking the same kinds of breaks from both.

>>6432744
I'm the same (ADHD and chronic procrastinator). It's like I can't physically move towards the drawing tablet. I procrastinate because of my perfectionism and I'm a perfectionist because of my rigid upbringing and other shit.

Found out, at least in my case, that that's an emotion regulation problem. Acceptance and Commitment Therapy is helping me. I had the belief that I needed to be all happy, content, motivated and with no anxiety at all to start working, but that's not true.

My anxiety is part of the alarm system of my mind trying to stop me from getting into another situation where I didn't achieve what I set out to do and got psychologically hurt. It just wants to protect me by keeping me in that comfort zone. It's like an overprotective mother that's afraid of letting her daughter get out of the house.

I stopped fighting against the anxiety. "Ok, I know you're just trying to protect me. Thank you. But I'm not you. I'm just feeling you and you're just an indicator, not a requirement. I can still act towards my long-term goals even when feeling you. I won't try to push you away, but I'm also not required to obey you."

You should take a look at ACT. It's good shit.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GnSHpBRLJrQ

I realized I was suffering from information overload. I'd wake up at 5 AM and go to bed at 10 PM and my mind wouldn't get a single second's rest. I'd jump from social media to Netflix to my work to social media again to reading something to listening to a podcast to thinking about the future to do some shit around the house etc.

My mind never had time to process and absorb all that shit I was cramming into it and it started giving me anxiety and a lack of focus as a cry for help.

I slowed way the fuck down and purposefully set some time blocks to do absolutely nothing, just lounge or stare out a window, shit like that. Let me tell you, my cigarette count went way down lmao

>>6434762
I can relate to everything you've said.
I'm also a perfectionist due my upbringing. I have brutal and straight up unfair standards for myself. I am genuinely disappointed when I underachieve. I'm too scared to start because I might not fulfill the high expectations I have for myself.
I'm scared of failing which triggers my anxiety hard.
Having high expectations and seeing art as work where I need to get results and not as something I get joy out of is one of the things I still struggle with.

But I've also learned during therapy not to fight against my anxiety.
I used to get extremely frustrated and angry at myself when I messed up and had an anxiety attack or when an unpleasant thought about the past popped up.
I've essentially had become my own bully and had continually shamed myself for my actions and inactions in the present and past.
Life is already hard enough, so why should I make it even harder by not working together with my thoughts and emotions?
My own body is not my enemy.
My thoughts and anxiety aren't panic alerts, they're reminders.
A reminder is not a cause to panic.

I have to keep reminding me of this fact everyday or else I slip into dooming again.

posts.com:
>>6435988
No, in the US and EU data scraping is protected by law because a fuckload of other technology requires it to function. It would cripple the internet as a whole if it weren't allowed.
Copyright law in the US also has a "de minimis" rule where small enough amounts of copying are not considered to be infringement. Any individual work scraped is such a small amount of the total that it easily passes that test. The only exception is if someone outputs something substantially similar to a copyrighted work, at which point they have to simply not share it.

Even the paid ones like MidJourney can probably avoid losing a case, for the same reason that games with microtransactions have you buy "credits" and then the credits are used for the actual store items rather than it being a direct monetary payment.

Just because it's not compressing images in the same way OTHER things do, doesn't mean that's not what's happening. You can read in the image that, and I quote:
>given an image x ∈ RH×W ×3 in RGB space, the encoder E encodes x into a latent representation z = E(x), and the decoder D reconstructs the image from the latent

I can read just fine. The article is in plain english, very simple and easy to understand.
>the image is encoded to the latent space

>every 'new' image is just an interpolation between two or more images

>when prompting, nothing 'new' is created, you just did the equivalent of a google search

If you did not create the image, you do not own the copyright.
If your program contains assets that are copyrighted, you cannot use it for profit. The dataset, containing all of the images it was trained on, is affected by the copyright status of its contents. Very simple. I highly doubt any new laws or changes to law would need to be made to come to this conclusion.

Ah, you're right, it's not an ethical or technical issue. It's a legal one. Because changing someone else's art until it's unrecognizable and then calling it yours is illegal. Written plain as day.

From what I understand, even taking the most conservative and technical arguments that you people have made, the model compresses images into a weighted model, uses said weights to create an image that is a combination of several, probably copyrighted image's weights, and then spits one out.

Is there any part of this process that you wouldn't define as "changing" another person's work? Maybe through some annoying semantic arguments, but courts don't tend to like those.

At best, generated images could be blanket considered transformative, but then it becomes a case-by-case basis on whether or not they infringe on the works of an original. And in the case of stylistically identical works? I think the court would tend to side with the owner of the original copyrighted works. And good luck trying to pass them off as "satire," read up on some infringement cases and tell me how often that works.

To clarify, I don't *believe* AI art is inherently a problem, it's a tool and like any tool there are positive and negative uses. I *believe* that it can and will be used by bad actors to infringe on the works of other artists, akin to tracing and theft, and that it's important that everyone understands that they are equivalent.

I don't think anyone would complain if websites or the law enforced putting a watermark or tag on any images generated by machine learning, and I don't think you can conceive of any negatives to that which wouldn't be hypocritical to your argument here. If it's really not cheating, then why would people have a problem tagging it as AI generated?

Latent space is basically the "memory" of the ML model. It's the data store of common features from the training data. i.e. a face has eyes, nose, mouth, has this shape, etc. If you really simplify ML down to the basics, ML is trying to find the optimal averages of various features of a subject and then storing those so it can roughly recreate the subject later. When you have millions of features the ability of an AI to generate various images becomes vast. This guy's entire argument is that ML can only generate something that it's been trained on but humans somehow produce outputs using data that they've never stored and is magical in that way. There's no real precedence for this sort of idea. Consciousness is a huge mystery for AGI researchers so there's no merit to making a claim one way or another. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6436560
>Algorithms interpolate between images
No, they literally do not do that. That's a misinterpretation at best, or at worst the graph did its job and misled your understanding. For one the images aren't there to interpolate. The entire point of the latent space is to break down immense data sets into a smaller set of data that is not only optimal to store and access when generating outputs, it's also a collection of averaged data from the training data. Your data doesn't exist in its original form anymore in the latent space anyway. It's already been optimized into oblivion by the model engine because it's not efficient to store a million unique images and then look through all of them and scramble bits and pieces together in real time. You can hypothetically reproduce a facsimile of a single image by asking for very specific parameters in the prompt, which would indicate over fitting on a small dataset, but more generally you'll get a new image that's a jumble of feature soup that the model has deemed a suitable representation of the prompt. IF that twitterfag is being honest about the "Afghan girl" prompt (unlikely) and that's what midjourney produced for a generic prompt, then it was simply a poorly trained model. ML is closer to monkeys reading millions of books and compiling various recurring plot points, themes, words, phrases, etc. in a way it's easy for them to understand into an encyclopedia and then using the encyclopedia to produce what you want.

Can the AI generate images nearly indistinguishable from an original piece, or that share undeniable traits of the artist's original piece?

"Style" cannot be considered, but "elements?" Absolutely. And AI doesn't use "style," it doesn't know what style *is,* but it knows the elements. Elements of an original are what are used to produce a new image, not style.

>In 2003, Pawan Sinha, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, set up a program in the framework of the Project Prakash[8] and eventually had the opportunity to find five individuals who satisfied the requirements for an experiment aimed at answering Molyneux's question experimentally. Prior to treatment, the subjects (aged 8 to 17) were only able to discriminate between light and dark, with two of them also being able to determine the direction of a bright light. The surgical treatments took place between 2007 and 2010, and quickly brought the relevant subject from total congenital blindness to fully seeing. A carefully designed test was submitted to each subject within the next 48 hours. Based on its result, the experimenters concluded that the answer to Molyneux's problem is, in short, "no". Although after restoration of sight, the subjects could distinguish between objects visually almost as effectively as they would do by touch alone, they were unable to form the connection between an object perceived using the two different senses. The correlation was barely better than if the subjects had guessed. They had no innate ability to transfer their tactile shape knowledge to the visual domain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6436720
The art produced by the model already exists within the latent space, and the model is simply a tool that we are using to explore and discover that art.
The latent space is a mathematical representation of the input data, and it captures the underlying structure and relationships within the data. It contains a wealth of information about the input data in a compressed form, and it represents the input data in a lower-dimensional space.

By using the model to generate new images, we are simply accessing and exploring the latent space, and we are finding images that already exist within that space. The model is not creating new art, but rather it is uncovering art that already exists within the latent space.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6436818
>When a painting is digitized it's turned into 0's and 1's and only a specific or set of algorithms can decode that for it to be visible on a screen.

Yes, that's correct. When a painting or other type of image is digitized, it is converted into a series of 0s and 1s, which is known as binary data. This process is often done using a process called sampling, which involves measuring the intensity of the colors in the image at regular intervals and representing them as a series of numbers.

To view the digitized image on a screen, a specific set of algorithms is used to decode the binary data and to create a visual representation of the image. These algorithms use the binary data to determine the colors and other visual characteristics of the image and to display them on the screen.
It is important to note that the process of digitizing an image involves a loss of information, as the original image is sampled and approximated using a finite number of digits. As a result, the digitized version of the image may not be an exact replica of the original, but rather a representation of it.

When you "explore" the latent space and use a machine learning model to generate new images or other data, the generated data is not literally created from scratch. Instead, it is generated based on the patterns and relationships that are present in the data and captured in the latent space.

However, it is not "created" in the sense that it is not produced by a creative process or human intervention. Instead, it is generated automatically by the machine learning model based on the patterns and relationships present in the data.

>>6436932
If you have 2 billion images(laion 5b minus the "low quality images") that are 64x64 pixels and each image is 4 kilobytes (KB) in size, then the total size of the images in gigabytes (GB) would be:

2,000,000,000 images * 4 KB/image = 8,000,000,000 KB
8,000,000,000 KB / 1024 KB/MB = 7812.5 MB
7812.5 MB / 1024 MB/GB = 7.62 GB

So in this case, the total size of the 2 billion images would be approximately 7.62 GB.

It's important to note that this calculation assumes that the images are uncompressed. If the images are stored in a compressed format, using some new fandan gled diffusion tech, you might get that down to half that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6436920
But they do already exist, just in the latent space, which is 100% fixed from the outset based on the input.
The libary of babel comparison is not really apt. The library of babel contains every single possible configuration of all 29 english characters, thus theoretically comprises all possible written words, infinite monkey theorem style. It extrapolates from a small number of elements to infinity.
However the latent space of a diffusion model is different. It is a set of X number of images plus all points of interpolated space between. It very much does NOT contain all possible images and pixel configurations, it is a set containing far less than that. The only possible "infinity" is that of a set of all decimal numbers between two real numbers, but this "infinity" is a smaller set contained within the set of ALL real numbers.

For all intents and purposes, everything that a latent diffusion model can generate is finite, and hard limited to what was input into it. If you trained a latent diffusion model on four images, the total set of images it could generate would be the original four images + every point of interpolation in between them. See picrelated for a good example. Everything within the model is derived from the input. All of it was determined from the start. You cannot get anything from outside of the interpolated space but noise. Even if you input billions of images and can generate more images than you could view in a lifetime, a human being can still create something that it cannot.

2,000,000,000 images * 64 pixels/image * 64 pixels/image * 32 bpp/pixel = 67,108,864,000,000 bpp
This is equivalent to approximately 67 terabytes (TB) of data.

here is a hypothetical example of how you might use different techniques to try to reduce the size of a dataset of 2 billion 64x64x32-bit images down to 4 gigabytes (GB):

Color quantization: By analyzing the distribution of colors in the images and selecting a set of representative colors, you might be able to reduce the number of bits required to represent each pixel, potentially decreasing the size of the dataset by 50%. This would result in a reduction of approximately 67 TB down to 33.5 TB.

Image compression: Using a lossy image compression algorithm, you might be able to achieve a further reduction in the size of the dataset by removing redundant or irrelevant information from the images. Depending on the specific algorithm and parameters used, you might be able to achieve a further reduction of 50% or more. This would result in a reduction of approximately 33.5 TB down to 16.75 TB.

Feature extraction: By identifying and extracting the most important or relevant features of the images, you might be able to further reduce the size of the dataset without losing too much information. Depending on the specific features that you extract and the method used, you might be able to achieve a further reduction of 50% or more. This would result in a reduction of approximately 16.75 TB down to 8.375 TB.

Dimensionality reduction: Using techniques such as PCA or SVD, you might be able to reduce the number of dimensions in the data and remove redundancy or irrelevance, potentially decreasing the size of the dataset by 50% or more. This would result in a reduction of approximately 8.375 TB down to 4.1875 TB.

So let me know if I understand this:

Programmers feed in data to some program that distills each into a set of parameters, and these distilled images become a data point

These data points are arranged in a multi-dimensional space, where similar data points are closer to one another.

Then the user enters in a prompt which creates a point that is somewhere in the multi-dimensional space.

Since that point probably won't land directly on a data point in the data set, it interpolates between data points to generate some kind of merged image from the neighboring data points.

Mathematically, there could be infinitely many data points to interpolate too, although with computers there are much less, but points that are closer to one another would look essentially the same to the human eye. Which means there's pretty much a limited number of points that can be interpolated to.

If I understand this correctly, no new images are being created. Images are just being interpolated between using whatever algorithm you pick. The AI doesn't know anything beyond the data set. It cannot extrapolate, which would create new images, like a human using their imagination. It can't mix and match different pieces of art based on whatever it feels like doing like humans do.\

This isn't art and you're not an artist.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6437024
That's generally correct. In a process known as "training," a machine learning model is fed a large dataset of input data and corresponding desired outputs. The model then "learns" to map the input data to the outputs by finding patterns and relationships in the data and adjusting a set of internal parameters to minimize the error between the model's predictions and the true outputs.
Once the model is trained, it can be used to generate outputs for new input data that it has not seen before. The model does this by using the learned relationships and patterns from the training data to make predictions for the new input data.

The process you described, where the model interpolates between data points in a multi-dimensional space to generate a new output, is a common technique used in machine learning, especially in the field of generative modeling. In this case, the model is not creating new images from scratch, but rather combining and manipulating the features of the training data in novel ways to produce new outputs that are similar to the training data.
It's important to note that the capabilities of a machine learning model are limited to the patterns and relationships it has learned from the training data. While it may be able to generate new outputs that are similar to the training data, it is generally not able to create entirely new and original outputs that are not based on the training data. This is because the model has not been exposed to any information beyond the training data and therefore does not have the ability to "imagine" or generate novel ideas in the way that a human might.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6435980
>color analogy
Basically, you know how gamuts are used to create specific pallettes, but cannot go beyond that without breaking the gamut? The latent space is that gamut of colors. You have a predefined set of colors: desaturated reddish-brown, bright pastel purple, neon turquoise, etc. Latent space can use these colors, but it cannot combine them properly. It also cannot go beyond the gamut for any reason.

Imagine if specific colors within a gamut had some sort of social media esque trendy upvote system. These upvotes assign priorities to some colors over others. Trendier colors gain a priority over non trendy colors within the gamut. This is bad for say, Copic, a popular company who has their rules about certain predefined colors. Copic sees that the only colors being selected are their own colors, and gets ass-mad: the only reason those colors were "trending" to begin with, was because of the copic brand.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6436882
>No matter what it feels like I'm doing something wrong, like there's something missing from my art or I just don't 'get' it and never will. It also feels like I already hit the ceiling in terms of improvement,
These two statements don't really make sense together. If something's wrong with your art then there's clearly room to improve.
I'm guessing you mean that you know something is wrong with your art but you don't know exactly what, which is a feel I know too and I get that it's super frustrating.
My advice is to do some master copies, find some artists you admire and try to do a piece of theirs from memory, then compare to see what you got wrong. Do some spaced repetition and see if you can start to understand their gesture, construction, shape language, composition, linework, rendering, whatever the hell it is about them you admire, just wear their skin for a bit until you start to internalize their methods. That gives you a clear goal to work towards and is one of the better ways to improve.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434338
NTA but yes and no. This is a subject I'm very familiar with and I get paranoid about a lot.
There's a lot to one's own psyche that you'll never be able to analyze properly and will influence your writing style beyond possible conscious recognition, so yes AI will do a better job identifying you than you can imagine.
However, looking at the entire internet, it's not that easy to identify one guy. There's a lot of other people out there with identical writing styles to you. Human language has a finite number of possible combinations. Double however, applying a filter to limit your search makes the technology a much greater danger.
For an example, if someone had your twitter history to build a model from, knew you posted on 4chan, had a specific time frame, limited their scope to archives of /pol/, maybe even a specific thread, then the number of distinct people they're picking from is a few thousand. a few hundred, or much less. They could get your posts with existing technology, assuming you're not a schizophrenic psychopath who makes an effort to write like a different person depending on what platform you're using or what part of your ideologies you're expressing. But probably only for posts of like 40 words or more, odds increase with word count obviously.
It's possible for humans to do this too, you've seen posts you can immediately identify as some specific schizoposter, like this one, if you browse the right boards you already know who I am. No AI required.
tl;dr The future won't actually be that much worse than the present, but the present is worse than you know, we're not waiting on technology for author recognition to cancel you, just for someone to make it an app.

Same, anon.
I'm trying to figure out how exactly tiktok works and it's actually worse than I expected.
Tiktok takes your location through IP address and recommends your content to people that have in common both the hashtag you put and your location. Meaning, if you're drawing for a very niche fandom or OC you can't get that far unless you spam videos like the plague to augment your chances of it spreading outside of your country, because literally everyone who likes/sees your video is from your country. Not to mention there's no sort by new search.
This is worse than twitter or Instagram because it inherently blocks distribution of content from smaller, non-corporate accounts. While on twitter and insta you can get 1k immediately with 1-2 posts if your art is good enough, tiktok just sends your video into a sample size of users from your country, which sucks ass if you're not american or Japanese/Chinese/Korean.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6436653
25/hr is shit tier for an artist. You have to compensate for the relatively low amount of hours you work if you want it to be sustainable.

Generally $60 per actual WORKING hr is a good starting point for your average coomer commission artist. You have additional overhead from talking with your client (can take upwards of 2hrs) and you may only get a few comms a week.

People generally don't value sketches so much if you actually LABEL it as a sketch, so if you're only doing sketch work just call them "commissions" and divide it by complexity. Like full body/halfbody/bust/portrait or whatever.

>>6436614
Yea but you still should be able to produce a complete sketch in 20-40 minutes. If you're spending much more time then that's not a "sketch" that's a full drawing. Efficiency is really key in any kind of professional (even solo) work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6436678
It can still be doable but in general purely-SFW commissioners are fewer and farther between because people just don't often value it.
You will sometimes get coomissioners who want their OCs drawn in SFW contexts though (like cosplaying a specific game or something).

But yes 60$ per working hour is what you want to aim for at the start. I have to emphasize that if you don't work fast enough you will not make it unless your quality is super fucking good for the time investment.

You have to think of it in the way that someone is not paying you for "a commission" but they're hiring you for a service. If that service is really fucking slow for the quality, then they're not gonna see it as worthwhile. If you spend 20 hours working on a drawing then whoever is paying you for that should basically be paying you the equivalent of a parttime job. Which means somewhere in the realm of 1200$ for the sheer fact you're a skilled artisan. But it has to be actually worth that price for someone to hire you for that long. If your 20 hour piece reasonably looks like a 5 hour piece because you spent 15 hours of ctrl+z (3 ctrl+z per stroke) over the course of it, you are fucking yourself and your clients over needlessly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6432333
It mostly boils down to mindset and tool use; gestural, free form approaches and soft leads will be what you tend to see with sketching, whereas lineart tends to see very deliberate stroke work and inks. Fundamentally though, you're using lines in either case to describe a view, and you can very well do both at the same time if you know how to approach that. They can absolutely overlap and playing around with various approaches can help you get there if you want.

Personally, I just stopped bothering about the distinction and kind of do both as needed to streamline my process and also get the best of both worlds, so to speak. If a sketch is neat enough it doesn't need to be mechanically traced over, and they often carry a quality to them you wouldn't get otherwise.

Ok that's fair. But I'd argue that REAL art is immune to ill effects of AI. Real art is not commercial art. People who are having their illustration or digital art jobs taken from them have already forsaken the essence of art and are simply craftsmen.

In a sense, that is how Art, with a capital "A", is defined. And anyone who posits that AI "learns" and "creates" something new doesn't understand what real art is.

Lastly, any real, traditional artists who has their art "stolen" wouldn't care. The AI can only make a digital facsimile of their physical art and anyone who would be a customer of the real artist wouldn't be interested in a digital facsimile.

The sky is falling on the internet for internet "artists." But they probably only make up a small percentage of everything and everyone that could be considered "art" or "artists."

Do the people that have created your tool actually have the rights to whatever you created with them?
>Free users don't get copyright. Paid users get transfer of copyright.
That's a legal issue, but based on the current laws, anything you create (if unique) you automatically hold the intellectual rights to it.
Copyright is another beast entirely that also implies distribution and usage rights (as in marketing, branding, etcetera).
>Training off of non-public domain images is another issue altogether, and there will be lawsuits soon to settle it one way or another.
That's another case entirely that cannot be discussed without the current, concrete proof and all the context around it.
If i say, i bought for access to an artists patreon, i automatically have the right to use the pictures as long as i don't distribute it or sell it, hence i can use it to train an algorithm to generate similar images, as per current law.
In the domain of copyright/intellectual property law, a style cannot be protected, only each individual work created is protected and belongs to the creator.
If it weren't this way, no one but the "firsts to create a style" would be allowed to produce and sell art.

The lawsuits could be very well end up doing absolutely nothing because the laws are there already and if they decided to ban AI for the sole reason of being a tool that makes a job better than the artist, then you will see governments getting sued and losing all credibility.

>But that would apply to any tool then.
Tool's don't create automatically create art by themselves, but the process of creating a tool could be considered art. Humans use tools to create art, but in this case the tool itself generates all of it by itself. If the tool does nearly all the work how much effort has the prompter put in?

The majority of existing artists and a lot of their followers don't consider that to be the case. This isn't the fine art where technique and effort are considered to be trade and not art, this is the mass online consumption art scene where public opinion of the masses dictate rules that artists and companies follow voluntarily if they want to participate. Current prevailing opinion is that effort does factor into art, and thus prompting alone would not be considered effort enough for the prompter to get receive the recognition for the art the tool generated.

I can create the charcoal and parchment to draw if absolutely needed to. Even a photographer could setup a pinhole camera and makeshift film if they didn't have access to a modern camera. I think you're one of the smarter anons here. People always put new filters in place. I think one of the major filters is going to actually be "customer service" because it's really been lacking among a lot of artists.
Basically if you're so shit to your clients that people would rather waste hours fiddling with an AI, you're going to have a bad time.

Additionally commissioners might use AI to generate references that they can then pay an artist to turn into an actual cohesive picture. And I don't mean like, normal comms, I mean the shit nobody commissions because it's too risky otherwise. Things that would get a commissioner blacklisted or which would cost 4x as much from the amount of corrections needed. People who are skilled enough to take such ideas that have been tempered by AI into a rough visual, will benefit enormously.
As an example, if you wanted say, some kind of hybrid of Dark Souls, but with the armor designs being a hybrid of Syd Mead-esque and Spiral Knights, getting the right look would be costly.

>>6418102
Push your contrasts. Physical media and monitors both have limited blacks and whites compared to real life. That's why you have sacrifice value range in either the shadows or the lit side to give a lifelike effect. Photographs don't do that by default to not lose information. There's too much contrast between small shapes while having a lack of proper light and dark seperation of major shapes.
If you adjust the contrast a bit on both and posterize you can notice these issues more easily.

posts.com: Say OP how do you position everything so accurately? How to train that skill?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6426324
I use a couple methods. If I’m drawing sight-size, I will drag a line across from the other image to locate the top and bottom of the head and other major features. Then it’s in the right place horizontally and I only need to figure out vertical placement. I did that with the first drawing. But I also use angles. I angle my pencil/charcoal against the line of the side of the face, the side of the forehead, etc., and then move over to my paper and start drawing while it’s still at that angle. This helps locate things too, because, for example, the angle of the nose and the eyebrow should meet at the right place and then I can place the eye. That’s what I mainly did for the second drawing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6428073
Because drawabox is dry and soulless as fuck. It will kill your motivation to continue drawing unless you are extremely autistic and can stick through with it.

There's also a huge drawback to being 100% practice 0% fun, and it's that you'll become good at only exercises and copying references for figure drawing and whatnot, but when you finally think of drawing what you always wanted, it will be super intimidating and if you can push past that, it will still look way worse.

Best way to learn is to mix both. Yes, you draw like a kindergartener, but next time you draw like a child, try to incorporate what you have learned so far into it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6432052
Probably. The method is just that. You can use tracing paper to check accuracy on your practice paper and that's what most traditional artists had been doing in the past. This method of study is usually called Master study but can be done as soon as you are just a beginner. It builds your ability to draw things correctly, transfering 3d objects onto 2d paper as well as building up your visual library. It's what artist had been doing for hundereds of years and a foolproof method. I know that this is hard when you just start out but be patient and you'll harvest sweet fruits in no time. Keep your way of methodology practice drawing as simple and direct as possible, consume solid knowledge from books written by foolproof professional artists (knowledge heavy based stuff like Color and Light by James Gurney rich visual enhhancement heavy based stuff like Monster Hunter Illustrations book).

See? It will be much more fun and much better than that "modernised revolutionary method" dab shit. There're many other book on perspective better than his shitty course (check out the artbook thread and download Dongho Kim's book for more comprehensible book on perspective)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6432069
You don't need to do bargue plates, the first lessons of the book was but simple shapes. You can practice more simple things if the plates are too hard to handle (for now) until you are more comfortable to start that book again (like pic rel). The point of this is you get to know how to build your own visual library which you will need to do a lot later whenever you learn something new related to drawing. Accuracy practice is the first step everyone should do. After that you'll actually know what to do without anyone telling you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The obsession with fineliners is really bad. There is no justification for it, he just copied Peter Han then doubled down despite not understanding the original reasoning.

Fineliners have some good properties in terms of playing well with other media but there are no advantages to using fineliners for the type of work you do in DaB. They behave exactly like rollerball or gel pens but are harder to buy and are delicate.

The biggest problem with learning on fineliners is that they are basically the only drawinging tool designed for a near-vertical writing angle so you spend a lot of time building muscle memory that doesn't apply to any other tool.
